product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: SierraJunkie
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. It might make more sense to review the "Initial Review" and then the "Update". Update:  After submitting this review on Amazon yesterday, I forwarded it to various emails at Netgear (Arlo is made by Netgear).  I received three phone calls and two emails attempting to help me with my situation.  Two new complete add-on camera kits were shipped to me as RMAs along with a postage paid return label.  All this arrived her within 24 hour of this original post.  Customer service really stepped up once I was able to get beyond the first level of support. The BATTERY CHARGE RESOLUTION... The source of the charging problem was the Arlo power adapter (white rectangular box)... both the one that came with the original cameras and the replacement power adapter were bad.  The original cables, camera and battery are all fine.  The new power adapter that came with the RMA add-on camera charge the new cameras as well as my original cameras.  I mentioned below that others suggested using a standard micro USB cable in place of the Arlo charging cable. I was told by a senior level Netgear support person that using a standard micro USB rather than the cable provided would not resolve any issue and in fact will not work.  I believe this to be the case. I am leaving this reviewed as a one star in hopes that it may draw attention to my experience and help others.  Having said that, I do really like the functionality of the cameras and software and I like the value of having no cloud storage fee.  Now that Netgear stepped up and my issues are resolved, I would recommend this product with the caveat that customer service is lacking.  I would give this product 4 stars. Initial Review: I loved this camera system for the first few months... until the batteries needed to be charged.  I am now more than a month into this and a dozen calls into Netgear's Philipine's-based call center and still no resolution.  After basic trouble shooting, I was told they would send a new USB charging cable and power supply.  A week later, the cable came... still no charge to battery.  After another call and another week, the power supply finally arrived... still no charge to battery.  After another call, I was told that the cameras would be swapped out... a week later and no cameras, no email indicating that the cameras would be shipped.  Several days later ANOTHER cable arrived (not sure why).  Another call and I was told that no camera replacements were authorized and that I needed to further troubleshoot.  We then upgraded the firmware... still no charge to battery.  I was then told that one last step was to replace the batteries (two cameras = two batteries).  A week later, ONE new battery arrived... new battery won't charge with new firmware, new cable and new power supply.  At this point, it doesn't take a genius to determine that the issue is the camera hardware.  Don't get me wrong, the steps seem logical but this should not take a month and a dozen calls.  Yet another call to Netgear support and I was told that we needed to upgrade the firmware of the second camera before customer support could authorize and escalation of the case... so that it could be FURTHER reviewed by a more senior level support group to determine IF new camera's could be authorized.  I was told I could not personally speak to anyone with the authority to order a replacement.  I now have a month of frustration into this and the best I can hope for are RMA cameras and the cost to ship back all the stuff they sent me along with the faulty cameras.  Hope you don't need support.  I see that others had similar charging issues and were able to resolve by using a standard USB cable.  That did not resolve my issue.
title: BEWARE - Battery charging issues and very poor support - Original Post Updated with Resolution

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Oriental Express
content: Got it for 3 weeks. I put it above the front door and the picture shows what it sees.  I've been playing with the motion sensor sensitivity for a while now and was unable to find the sweet spot. (Perhaps there's no sweet spot for my case). I have the base station sensitivity set to 100% and the camera set to 95%.  Below is when I'll get an alert. YES = Motion detected and I got an alert. NO = No motion detected and no alert. - Someone walks on the walkway and approaches the front door.  YES - Someone walks on the sidewalk on the far right, from either direction, day or night.  YES - Any activities happen on the lawn on the right.  YES - A bug flys by the camera.  YES - I back the car (a white minivan) out of the garage.  (Grey car is facing the garage).  NO - I walk to the grey car from garage, get in, and drive away.  NO - I pull the car up from the street to the driveway, get out, and walk to the garage.  NO - I should say, ANY ACTIVITIES happen on the asphalt driveway.  NO - Cars drive by on street.  NO - Garbage truck picks up my garbage by the curb.  NO - Mail carrier deliver mail into curbside mailbox.  NO I know the ideal distance is less than 20ft. The camera is about 18ft from the grey car and from the sidewalk. Not sure why it wouldn't pick up anyone or anything in the driveway but would pick up anything on the side walk. I deemed this useless if it can't even capture anything on the driveway which is not that far away and nothing is obstructing its view. Night vision is limited to objects near the camera. It can't see anything far away.  If someone is really trying to break into our cars at night, the camera won't do anything.  This is a very pricey camera and I expected much more.  I'm returning it. Update 10/29 : I didn’t return it but moved it above the garage door. With the sensitivity set to 100%, it wouldn’t be even detect when my car backs out of the garage or pull in to the garage. It’s literally 4 ft from my car and it does not detect it. I deemed this camera useless.
title: Unreliable motion detection

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Ken
content: This seemed really promising but ultimately it's a big disappointment. The biggest issue is it only records when it detects motion but the motion detection is really bad. For example I set one up in my garage to alert me when the door is opened thinking it would start recording right when the door moves, however it doesn't start recording the clip until maybe a second after the garage door is completely up. The other cameras I can very easily just walk past without being recorded. *If* they offered a continuous recording option for these wireless cameras they would be amazing. The hardware is really nice and the wireless is fantastic. Without continuous recording they're nearly useless for security though. I'd even worry they make my house more of a target than they would be a deterrent just because anyone familiar with them would know they could run up and pull them off. I would recommend avoiding these until they make improvements.
title: Really poor motion detection

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Alex
content: I used to have 2 cameras of the Arlo Wire-Free and migrated them to the new Arlo Pro base station and added 6 additional cameras to put them around the house. If I leave the system armed all the time so it records motion to the cloud, batteries on the cameras last 2-3 days at the most as there is always movement triggering the camera's recording. If I leave all cameras streaming on the app or website so I can watch the feed live, after a few minutes the app on iOS (iPad and iPhone) simply closes by itself and the website just stops the live feeds. And if you're watching the live feed, the camera isn't recording the motion to the cloud (defeats the purpose!). I use it with Samsung's SmartThings Hub, but I've had a few alarm triggers because I forgot to disarm it before walking into the house and some of the Arlo cameras failed to record when called by SmartThings. SmartThings native sensors work great so far (motion, open/close, etc.), but Arlo cameras are disappointing. I also have an Arlo Q setup with Arlo's Continuous Video Recording plan and have the same issues on the app and website for live streaming. It just stops and closes the app/website. Accessing the history form the continuous video recording feed is a pain, slow and it doesn't always record. I tried using the Arlo Q for baby monitoring, but because the app/website can't sustain live streaming for more than a few minutes, I gave up and bought a Nest Cam. Totally different experience, the Nest's live streaming is real-time (Arlo's has at least a 3 second delay) and it's totally seamless to rewind/fast-forward on the Nest app or website. Nest also has a live streaming URL that you can share with anyone. The downside is that Nest charges you the subscription if you want to record anything in the cloud (Arlo's advantage is the wireless factor and the free recording to the cloud when a camera captures motion/sound). The quality of the image in all Arlos is great, the app is great, the website live feed is great (despite the 3 second delay). But the system itself is not reliable. So if you're looking for occasional peeking, not continuous live streaming, and a reliable security video system, this is not the right option. Although I'm fully committed to Arlo by now with the current investment, I'm looking for wireless, battery-powered cameras that I could use to replace Arlo Pro because I can't really put up a 6ft ladder every 3 days to take the cameras down, recharge and put them back up. The whole point of wireless was because I didn't want to run the wires through tough spots, but convenience backfired on my case. If anyone knows of better alternatives to the Arlo wireless cameras, please let me know!
title: Not a reliable security system, battery doesn't last

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Chris Majestic
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. The Arlo Pro is a new and improved version of the original Arlo System. It is 100% Wire-Free as the cameras run on battery power and communicate wirelessly to the included Base Station. The base station must be wired directly to your router but connects wirelessly to the cameras. The base station supports up to 5 cameras and has a built-in 100db siren. The Arlo Pro system isn't perfect but it works really well and I would recommend it to to someone who can't run wires for a more traditional security camera system. Pros: 100% Wireless Cameras Super Easy Setup Lots of options and settings Weather Resistant Cons: Highly compressed HD video. (Not always clear) Batteries only last 3-6 months and even less at Best Video Quality Limited to 5 cameras total Recordings are limited to 2 minutes
title: Great wireless camera solution but not perfect

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Mystery
content: Great concept, poor performance. Main issues: 1) motion detection is slow by quite a few seconds missing important footage (even with latest firmware), 2) I set it to continuously record yet most of my clips are only 16, 18, 21 seconds long. It stops recording when there is activity going on and doesn't even start recording again missing important details, 3) arlo.netgear.com is flash only...its 2017!! this needs to be updated to HTML5 ASAP!! Real world battery life TBD. Again, great concept, but poor performance. Adding: 4) the battery only lasts a couple days in a high traffic area and, 5) they don't even provide you with a weatherproof usb cable for continuous charging! Adding: 6) image quality is not HD. 7) recordings some times are distorted and have artifacts, 8) one of my cameras appears to have died just at the 30 day mark. Looks like I will be returning this junk and trying Nest. Adding: 9) One thing I noticed is that when the lens got wet, it would take hours for it to dry to be able to see. The nest some how can see through a rainstorm. Is the Arlo missing some protective coating or something?
title: Junk JUNK JUNK!!! Great concept, poor performance

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Really!?!
content: So close but yet so far from being the right choice. I bought this unit because we didn't want wires running down our tree where we could set it up. Finally we found Arlo. It seems like the right solution and it is but not without its own issues. I wish I could have given this a 2.5 star rating. Hooking up the unit to the existing wifi turned out to be a giant issue which took me hours. I couldn't get the camera to work even though it was hooked up to the base station. In comes Netgear support. By the time I was done with them, they had "joined" my computer, went through my internet settings and told me that I had unwanted users on my network which is the reason why the secure camera won't work. Then they wanted close to $400 to fix the issue. Ah... No. There were no unwanted users on my network. But just in case and considering Netgear was on my computer, I decided to reset my router and change the password. Once I did that here's what I did: Syncing to Wifi: Reset Router and only connected my personal Macbook Pro laptop. Reset and synced the Arlo Base Station and Camera - VIOLA!! It worked. Proceeded to reconnect all other devices one by one and Arlo stayed connected. Installing the camera: Installation was a breeze. I have it hanging from a tree in the front of my house. The downside is access, which I need a ladder to get to. It comes with a half round metal adapter that the Arlo Pro camera connects to either on top of the camera for ceiling mount or on the back for wall mount. The camera has a very strong magnetic for the mount which is great. Picture quality: There are 3 settings. Even on the "lowest quality" setting that's suppose to save battery life, it's not bad. Battery Life:*UPDATE Here's the downside. Arlo Pro has its own battery, meaning this unit is not powered by off the shelf batteries. I live in a high traffic area, which is a HUGE issue with Arlo's battery. The battery comes fully charged and after installing it lasted about 5 days. Now, I have to recharge it daily. It takes 1 hour to charge, but that isn't enough to adequately charge it. Netgear offers individual batteries, but here's the catch - a battery charger is not available as of this posting.  This means that I must climb a ladder daily to recharge. *UPDATE - I have a "workaround" for the battery life. Since my camera is up in a tree which I need a ladder to access it, I hooked up the USB cord and let it rest on the limb. When I need to charge, I hook up the plug and run an extension cord to it. I let it charge for a few hours and now my camera has power for about 3 to 4 days. Software Interface: Everything is cloud base, which I like for the most part. Getting to the camera settings to adjust length of recording and picture quality is a bit confusing the first few times simply because it doesn't feel intuitive. But once you figure it out, it's fine. Recording: Here's another issue. Length of recording and sensitivity of the camera to start recording. The default length is :10 seconds. You can change this up to 2 minutes. Once that time length is reached, the recording stops, even if there's still movement going on. I've had a few times where I wanted to see what was happening past the end. I need to do a little more trial and error for best results. Recording Storage: Netgear has a free, 1gb, 7 day storage. You can view your library online and download the videos you want to keep. There are other option to keep the storage longer and more storage space. There is an USB option, which I haven't tried yet which allows me to backup my videos in real time as they're being recorded on Netgears cloud servers. Reviewing the videos is easy on your Arlo interface. Infrared at night: Works great with a clear picture. Will I keep it? Yes. Could it be better? Yes. Pros: Nice look. Good picture and decent sound quality Storage of videos and review process USB backup of videos in real time. Get's the job done Cons: Not completely plug and play Cloud based interface of camera settings not intuitive Battery life for high traffic area is 1 day Battery replacement is horrendous No external battery charger for extra battery available yet. *UPDATE - The way it records is an issue. You can only choose blocks of time to record from :05 seconds to 2:00 minutes. Because the camera is motion or sound sensitive it chooses when something is moving. But it won't start recording again immediately after it stops recording even if something is moving. Also there's no way of recording constantly such as a few frames every :05 seconds.
title: It has all the right parts, but it's not quite there - yet.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Kevin Duffey
content: Having tried several different types of cameras over the years, the Arlo Pro system has just about everything you need for a security camera, especially when you factor in the free 7 days of cloud storage as well as the ability to record to a local USB thumb drive. I say just about because the one issue as many have pointed out is in high traffic areas, the battery will run down pretty quickly... though I have not personally tested this. To circumvent this, specifically as an outdoors camera, I feel that every Arlo Pro camera should make use of an external power source to keep the battery always charged. I opted for the somewhat expensive but hopefully reliable solar panels that run about $70 each. If mounted along side the camera (and at a distance high enough up or hard enough to get to to avoid someone unplugging it and/or taking them), assuming you get a bit of sun from time to time, the camera should not require a hard wired power source. I can not however back up that claim in areas that rain a lot or have a lot of cloud cover.. as I have read that that will result in the solar chargers barely putting out much juice. That said, lets hope most owners have a little bit of sunlight at least once every few weeks so that the charger can replenish the battery on the camera enough to keep it going continuously. The other thing, which many reviews have indicated is the magnetic mount that the camera comes with leaves a bit of doubt as to someone pulling the camera off of it and taking it. If the camera is mounted high enough, it will be less of a problem, but even so, as strong as the magnet is, I still have my doubts if it will withstand strong windy gusts.. or someone trying to hit it with a ball to knock it down. Therefore, the screw in mount seems like the option that should come with every camera, and given they are an additional $15 or so, and the price of these cameras, I would suggest buying them (and possibly the Arlo cameras coming with them in the future). The quality of video is fantastic, even with a 2 to 3 second lag. The Wifi range is pretty good from what I can tell. I havent had it long enough to determine if there are a lot of false triggers, but Arlo just announced a new AI that will supposedly figure out humans, animals and vehicles that should reduce that... though I am hoping it is not an extra cost to take advantage of that on a monthly basis... hoping its a firmware/software update that doesnt cost anything.
title: Fantastic Camera for Security

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: NJ Devs
content: Product Support = F- This has to top one of my worst "Product Support" experiences in recent years. The "CHAT" icon in the web-based program just takes you to an open window with the word "CHAT" in it. You think that someone will soon log on to speak with you but my advice is don't wait too long because nothing is going to happen. In light of this, I called several times and was .... best case ..... 5 in the queue. When it took 20 minutes to become #4, I figure it best to call at night. I call this morning at 3:00 AM and was #3 in the queue. It was 1 hr and 10 minutes before the agent picked up. Very nice gentlemen but wasn't really trained with working knowledge of the system. All he could offer was the same troubleshooting steps that I could get on the website. I have 7 cameras on my system... all configured the same. One of them is not responding to motion at any sensitivity at any range. The only way I can get it to record is a manual trigger. You would think that just shear logic would tell you that it's a malfunctioning piece of equipment but yet the agent put me through the painful process of the troubleshooting steps that got us nowhere. One step was a complete wipe and re-configuration of the entire setup. Frustrating to say the least but it got me to the next step which is an email telling me that my situation was being elevated to the next step and that I'd be hearing from an "expert" in the near future. I can't wait to waste more time talking to him about this. Now let's talk about design- in theory B+ - in reality C-. It's a completely wireless system which is every enthusiasts dream..... but.... the battery depletes over time and the higher demand and desired functions selected, that time decreases exponentially. So you want high resolution at maximum sensitivity and all the notifications etc.... be prepared to charge those batteries quite a bit. Is that a big deal you ask.... take the time to situate your cameras exactly how you want them and then you can write your own review about the goat rope you just went through. The exterior mounts are pure garbage. Just when you have the camera set exactly the way you want.... you torque down on the set feature and the whole camera begins to turn so now you have to calculate how much your camera is going to move as you set the torque so they both end up where you want when the torque finally sets. Do this while you're on a ladder overlooking your driveway or your front door. Play a little circus music in the background too. It's fun. The interior mounts don't trail too far behind. Magnetic- easy/peasy but the person that designed these must have slept through Physics 101. They are round and mount to the wall similar to a picture frame. Put the screw in, find the hole, and slide it down. If your camera is attached perfect to the centerline of the slide, you're in business.... but.... if you want to offset it to the right or the left, go find that circus music and start it again. Any deviation from the centerline of the mount causes the camera to tilt in the opposite direction... and other than putting a stop pin along side the mount, there is no way to stop this rotation unless you use glue. I elected not to use glue because this setup is going in the trash just like my last one did. Now let's talk features....I'm not even going to grade this because they are all a joke. They have this Arlo Smart feature - let's take at look at each one. Package detection - misleading. it doesn't detect packages, it detects the person delivering the package. You're not going to get a message that you have a package. I don't really need to activate this feature because the system already inherently does that. You can, however, manually log into that camera to see if that motion alarm was in fact a package delivery or just simply stream the camera video live and see for yourself. E911 - will call the 911 region where your system is based. A nice feature but I can also call the police station directly from my phone speed dial. Ill give them this one though. It has its merits. Activity Zones - complete nonsense. Unless your surveilling a parking lot you don't need zones. When you actually set these up and try to use them, you're going to realize that in most rooms, theres no way to avoid stepping into a zone (or avoiding one) you set up. If your rooms are that big where you need to set up zones..... you'll have the resources to buy a much better system than this and not be the one fussing with it. Then let's get to the cherry on the cake. If you keep your system to 5 cameras or less, you get free iCloud recording for 7 days. Wow.... generous....thats enough storage to go on vacation and come back to overwrite the burglars that broke into your house 6 days ago. You can buy a hard drive and attach it to avoid this and I highly recommend it. You're going to love this system so much that you going to want to go out and buy another camera. Well, congrats! You just became a premium member because your free service ends at 5 cameras. All the hard disk space in the world isn't going to get you out of paying this fee. Well, alas..... Im stuck because I bought all this garbage at just under a cool G spot and now I have to wait until it to finds its place in the eternal landscape at the county grounds. Would I make this mistake again? NO FREAKING WAY! It is easy to set up and start using. I liked that. I hope everything works. If not, return it for another. You'll get a quicker turn on a functioning product. Edit added 12/09/18 I just went through the painful process of convincing Arlo that the camera was defective. Unbelievably ridiculous! To add to the frustration, 12 days after I signed up for Premium Service they emailed me an offer for 4 months free. I contacted Customer Service in the same painful manner and they denied extending me the offer stating that I was a previous customer and the offer didn't apply. I signed up 12 days ago. This will be the last Netgear product I will ever purchase. They have no concept of customer service. Very disappointed I invested in this nonsense.
title: Think Again - WAY overpriced and absolutely the worst Product Support in the business.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: NY person
content: This product is a very good concept, but the execution of the software is terrible, and compounding this is that it's been this way for a long time. The hardware itself is decent, as the camera works well and works the way it's supposed to.  Video quality is good.  Motion detection seems to work pretty well too.  However, it's the software that enables this system to work as a security device, and it's horrible.  The app takes a very long time to log in, and over time it's actually gotten worse.  It used to be that only logging in was slow, but now it often hangs when I'm trying to access the mode screen to change modes.  When a video is sent via email, the link to view the video does not work--you have to go into the app itself. The geofencing feature would be a very cool feature--if it worked.  It had been in beta for a long time, but even after beta ended, it still doesn't work properly--worse even.  The geofencing no longer properly detects when you are at home or away, and can randomly just go on away mode when you're in the house.  Of course it will then start taking videos of you and emailing them to you, which you might not realize until 20 emails later. In short, this system is infuriating.  Taking a long time log in might not seem like a big deal in concept, but keep in mind you are often trying to configure this thing on the run, on your way out, etc.  And if you use this as a security system, imagine getting an unexpected notification that your cameras have detected motion at home--then not being able to access the video to see what's going on (fire?  burglar?). Since this system is fairly innovative, I would give them a free pass for initial buggy systems if they eventually fixed them.  Or if they were continually adding more and more cool features, thus giving them an excuse for breaking other aspects of the software.  Unfortunately, the bugs that existed are still unfixed, new ones are being introduced, and there doesn't seem to be any expansion of functionality (although this Arlo pro camera, is new). I bought this along with a 2 camera set around the same time.  Now, I'm regretting it and afraid to expand to more cameras given Arlo's inexplicable inability to fix anything.  Try looking up some of the issues you experience, and you'll see them being discussed in forums years ago.  What kind of company ignores these basic functionality defects?
title: Very bad software and app offsets decent hardware

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Diann L. Smith
content: 10/31/2017 Update:  Down to 1 star for continuing to waste my time and I still do not have a working base station.  I have received a call and several emails promising that while the company's normal policy is that customers must pay packing and postage to return defective products during the warranty period, they will waive that policy.  I have been repeatedly promised a prepaid label, but have never received it.  Instead, I receive similar emails telling me to fill out a standard form in which I have to choose whether to pay for shipping up front or pay my own postage. 10/20/2017 Update:  Decreased stars from 3 to 2.  1 year warranty requires customer to pay to ship defective product back and then wait for replacement.  I appreciate the response from the company to this review; however, customer service remains very difficult.  The "experts" just don't have an appropriate script to follow.  The new one I talked to -- who was much more helpful than the first one -- did not seem to know the process and put me on hold several times, only to come back with more questions.  In total I was on the phone for about 40 minutes and was told it would take another 20 minutes to finish.  I said I did not have the time and I was told I could hang up an the process would finish without me.  As to the "expert" trying to help me with a base station that would not turn on, sometimes the questions related to the camera, the internet connection, etc -- even though the only issue was that the base station would not turn on.  When she finally agreed to replace my unit, she sent me an email to confirm.  For the first time the email noted that I, the customer that received a defective unit, would have to (a) pay shipping to return the unit and (b) package the unit up in my own packaging.  Other, more customer friendly companies, send you prepaid packaging to return defective products. Original:  The camera is fantastic -- the base station has a problem and customer service is a disaster.  The camera has a great picture and the battery lasted 5 months before charging.  Oddly, the battery showed that it was low about 3 months in but I just left it on and it has not run out yet.  The problem is the base station and customer service.  The base station stopped powering on.  From reviewing various help forums this seems to be a common problem.  I am in the U.S. but Netgear/Arlo seems to claim this is only an int'l issue.  I did all of the things suggested on the website support and nothing worked.  So I called customer service.  The representative (euphemistically called an "expert") had no idea what she was talking about.  She fundamentally did not understand that there was a difference between the camera and the base station.  She repeatedly asked me the exact same question and kept putting me on hold, coming back and asking the same questions again.  She asked me for a serial number 3 separate times.  When I asked to speak to someone else, she merely kept reading a script that appeared to be for a different product than mine.  My base station is still not working.
title: Failed base station, incompetent customer service, warranty of limited use.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: AaronR
content: Like many others, I was lured into buying this device to complement my other Arlo cameras because of the reviews.  However, the weak link with this camera is the battery.  Take a moment to read the reviews of the replacement battery before you purchase the Arlo Pro.  My battery lasted just over a year before it stopped accepting a charge.  This is not uncommon and many others report much shorter life spans for the battery.  The replacement battery is $48.  Not good.  While this camera may be good in general for features and perhaps for long term corded use, the battery doesn't appear to last long and is wildly overpriced. 29% 1 star reviews at the time of this review for the replacement battery here: https://www.amazon.com/Arlo-Pro-NETGEAR-Rechargeable-Battery/dp/B01LYCMLY5/ref=sr_1_3?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1536597974&sr=1-3&keywords=arlo+pro+battery#customerReviews
title: Before you buy this device check the reviews for the replacement battery

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: IMNSHO
content: I purchased the ARLO Pro with 2 cameras, and while it worked, the system was useful. However, one camera stopped working, and after charging both batteries, it was evident that one of the cameras was defective. Both batteries worked in the second camera. I called tech support. First, it was difficult to understand the technician's English. Second, the background noise of other technicians was very loud, making it challenging to hear the technician's words. After being on the phone for more than an hour, trying this and that, the technician first told me that my network was infected and I needed to purchase either a one/two/year plan. I opted for the $99 one year plan (not fully understanding what it was I was purchasing, and I get that was foolish of me).  After next paying that sum, the technician determined that the camera was indeed defective, and that I was eligible for a replacement.  He forwarded me to "hardware" support and asked that I charge both batteries and call back his number. I spoke with hardware support, gave all the details to receive an RMA order, and then called back technical support. This time I got a different technician.  I gave him my CASE #, and I was told the problem was the battery.  I do not want to bore everyone with the details, but suffice it to say, after waiting online and then speaking to a supervisor, it was agreed that the problem was the camera. The email with the RMA that I completed was poorly connected.  I will shipo out the defective camera to TN. Who knows if and when I will get a replacement. Terrible, disconnected, misleading service. And in my book, ARLO deserves a one star.
title: frustrating run-around customer service

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Leialoha
content: Ive purchased this for 2 different houses I have. Installing them into place is really simple. However getting the cameras to pair with the hub was a challenge. Both sets would have a period of time where it didnt wanna connect(if you follow the app prompts) it would just simply sit there giving no indication on what the hell it was doing. So skip the steps on the app for pairing just hold the sync button on the hub then once that gives the wink do the same with the camera and......money!! Once that headaches over, then you have to wait for the cameras to update ( cameras do nothing this entire time) seriously wtf cameras have to update out the box for. Anyway the cameras have never had to update since initial setup. However the app seems like it needs updating every couple days. Also I might add that once the cameras are updated which in my case it didnt really notify me it was done, you will need to log out of the account and log back in. I learned alot of these little quirks on the fly. Im for the most part tech savy. I would not recommend having tech challenged people set this up, go get someone with a PHD to fire this up for you. Lol Once all that is completely out of the way the camera views are wide angle, night vision works very well. You really need to consider position where you put the cameras. Motion is picked up from the sides of the cameras. So for example dont put a camera at an opposite wall facing a door, the camera may or may not pick it up in time. The cameras have maybe a 10-15 sec delay, its not instant. So when I use the live feature and try to speak through the camera the response from the other end takes a few. Having a few houses hooked up is a breeze to manage from 1 account. I set up 2 diff accounts, 1 for each house then just invited 1 to the other. I have all the cameras in 1 laundry list to choose from. I can arm 1 full time and geo arm the other for when my family leaves the house. Battery life is very good. I havent charged 1 set for about 3 months so far, even with curious birds flapping at them to see what it is. Even bees will set these dudes off until you adjust the sensitivity. That being said final thought, its an awesome package that doesnt require a monthly service. It will not notify authorities but there are other features you can purchase for monthly service they may include this feature, what I use it for works for me ( the volume of the alarm will definitely hurry along intruders). Battery life is superb, its wireless doesnt use much internet usage, or even require incredibly fast speeds. The app is extremely user friendly and easy to check cameras or arm or just mess with family when your bored at work. I hated the setup both times, I would rather jump in the ring with a professional fighter for the length of time it took to set these dudes up. I appologize for the lengthy review hopefully it helps clearify a few things, now go have a cold 1 before you engage in the purchase.
title: Awesome once its running.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Brandon
content: I installed these cameras on my home last year and they worked that season really well. I also purchased solar panels to help with the time I would need to climb up there to recharge the batteries. Early this year, I noticed some of the cameras (then all of them) stopped working, because they were disconnected from the hub. I called customer service and they weren’t helpful at all. Basically the response was, reconnect them, without actually addressing why they disconnected in the first place. They all got reconnected but I noticed they had much less range for some reason. They only picked up motion around 25%-30% of the time. Fairly recently, they stopped working all together. One disconnected again, while the others don’t pick up motion at all. I honestly can’t think of the last time I got a notification for motion. These cameras are great for the first year, but after that, they’re garbage. Almost literally garbage since customer service won’t truly help me with fixing them, since they’re out of warranty...
title: Bricks after a year

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Super-Shopper
content: The Arlo Pro is a great idea in concept but not so great in execution.  There are constant connectivity issues even though the camera is close (line of sight) to the base station. The battery drain is also fairly quick.  There was also a recently introduced bug (after a firmware update) where the highly crucial (at least for me) Push-to-Talk feature no longer works.  When you connect to "talk" through the camera's speaker, the camera's microphone is permanently shut off (even after you stop holding the talk button), so there is no way to have a two-way conversation, for example with a delivery person at your door, etc.  This feature used to work fine before the firmware update.  We contacted Arlo on their support website (where several other folks reported the same exact issue) but no response from Arlo, yet another reason for the low rating.  Arlo, please step up and actually SUPPORT your products.
title: Constant Issues

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Mike H
content: I've had my Arlo cameras for over a year now and the video display is very poor even when set to best image. When trying to view live video, the images freeze more than display. I get a second of live display then 10 seconds of waiting. I am very frustrated with this product for the price. As a comparison, I also have a Nest Hello Doorbell. The Nest is 100 times better in picture quality and display. The live video is seemless with no interruptions. The Nest records every second for up to 7 days and shows "dots" where it saw motion or heard a loud noise. When my Arlo cameras pick up motion, I am sent a notification on my phone about 1.5 minutes later. With Nest, the notification occurrs within 10 seconds. Don't bother buying this version of Arlo. Pure junk for an expensive price!!!
title: Not worth the money

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: CoffeeLover
content: I bought this system to monitor my house in another country. While the quality is okay when it works, and I like the free 7 days of recordings,  my home is in an area where there are occasional power outages. When the power comes back on, the base station fails to re-connect to the router 100 percent of the time, and thus I lose my security camera! Apparently, the problem is that my fiber modem/router takes about 60 seconds to boot up after the power comes back on, and the Arlo base station boots up much faster and thus never gets an IP address. It tries early, but then never again. Arlo troubleshooting  documents say ”router must be up and available before Arlo. To fix, reboot your base station.” Which, of course, is impossible when you are 6000 miles away. There’s nobody in my house to reboot the base station. This is totally lame design. I do not have this problem with the Arlo WiFi cameras, by the way. They all connect no matter what order router/camera is ready. This base station is thus not for serious security use in a home that you leave unoccupied for months at a time. Essentially it’s just a “security toy”.
title: Useless if installed in an area with occasional power outages

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Timothy J Surber
content: Ordered this to have a security system with cameras. I followed the step by step instructions that came with the product. To link your cameras, they are supposed to have a QR code on them to read. My did not have them. They give you an option incase there is not a QR code, your phone, through your Arlo app, creates a QR code that the camera is supposed to read. Once the camera reads it, it is supposed to chime. Both cameras, no chime and unable to locate device. Tried going to support on Arlo.com. Zero help, the chat feature does not work, and the send an email feature does not work either. o the basic message from Arlo is "we are here to help, as long as you do not have an issue". Avoid this product, equipment quality is poor and the support is worse.
title: Both Cameras Dead On Arrival

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: K
content: Have been an arlo supporter for many years and upgraded each time, but now we are going to switch. 1. Delayed Images - We have extremely good wifi in our house but the Arlo images are delayed by anything from 30 seconds to 5 minutes. I should not receive an alert almost 5 minutes after something happened. It has become a joke for us to play with the dogs outside and then come back in and watch ourselves in "arlo live realtime" go out the door, and play with the dogs and evenually come back in. 2. We have our cameras connected to power so we dont have to worry about re-charging constantly. But we find randomly the camera will stop and report message to either change battery or that we have an unauthorized cable connection. We take it down, leave it for 12 hours and then plug back in and all is fine again until the next time it randomly stops. I really wanted to love it but it just seems like they are falling behind what are now much cheaper alternatives. :(
title: Delayed Images and issues with power connection

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Filmhits
content: Arlo Pro by NETGEAR Security System Kit with Siren - 3 Arlo Pro Camera System and Indoor/Outdoor Mounts (AVM4000C) I am an Audio and Video Engineer, therefore I spent a good amount of time researching Security Cameras, and ultimately decided upon the Arlo Pro  by Netgear. THE GOOD: 1:Easy Installation. (I had my Son instal lit to see the procedure done by  a non-Professional. It took him 15 Minutes to set up. 2:1080 Picture quality  is  excellent. (do not buy any camera with 720p, or less than 1080 Pixels.) 3:Excellent  Audio quality to listen  as well as to speak to anyone  on the live  video. 4:Very Good Night recording capabilities, although the distance is limited to about 50 feet or so. 5:Free Cloud subscription (for a week of saved  recordings.) One can pay more for longer  saving time, however, one can  download the videos you like, or want to save to your computer. THE "INCONVENIENCES" 1:Battery Life  will last several months UNLESS, it is used on a daily basis, such as monitoring an area, then the battery must be recharges after about 2 weeks or so, which meand taking the camera down to recharge it (Unless you order a separate Recharger,which is about $60.00 )(https://www.amazon.com/Arlo-Pro-NETGEAR-Charging-Station/dp/B01LXPAY47/ref=sr_1_3?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1516386971&sr=1-3&keywords=ARLO+BATTERY+CHARGER 2:Delay: There is about a 4 second delay from the time the camera detects movement until it records the video. 3: It uses 2.4 Gigaherz Wi-fi. Hopefully  it will be updated to receive 5.0 Gig in the  future (Faster Speed). 4:User can use as is, or Set the parameters as to when the Camera records (Loud Sounds, Movement,) But sometimes records  items moving because of  strong winds, or loud noises. This can be adjusted in the settings for each camera. 5:User can use the camera(s) Wired, instead on Wi-Fi, however, at this time  the Cable wire is being recalled by Arlo. All In All, one of the better Security cameras on  the market today.
title: GREAT SYSTEM-WITH A FEW  MANAGEABLE INCONVENIENCES.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: John Leonard
content: battery life is a lie. upon original install the battery lasted about 3 weeks. i have since recharged the battery and in less than a week it is down to 78%. this camera is used in the front of the house pointed at my driveway so there is a lot of movement. i am a naturally skeptical person when it comes to things but i was not prepared for the battery life to be so poor. so right now i have a dilemma, i have already invested a few hundred dollars in the system so i don't want to start over but the poor battery life limits where i was going to place the cameras. what i may try to do is place the cameras in places where i can run power cables to and use the batteries as back up in case of power failure or if someone unplugs them thinking they will no longer work. apart from the poor battery life the cameras perform well and are easy to install in out of the way places. i also supplement this system with arlo q indoor cameras.you can place these in windows to use as outside facing cameras. they work very well. both cameras are easy to set up they say the batteries will last 4 to 6 months with normal use. they say normal use is recording 4 minutes a day. if you have a normal house with kids and pets there is no way the camera will only record 4 minutes a day. keep this in mind when making your purchase.
title: do not believe that battery rating.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Kevin B.
content: Edit #2: Wow, now the entire base unit randomly turned off! It was working fine at 9am. I go plug in a camera (cause the battery life is terrible) and a few minutes later I notice all cameras have no connection.  I look and they are all powered off and the base unit has no connectivity! All other internet devices are still working in the house.  I will be returning this system if an immediate fix is not identified. New Edit: What trash! I set this up on Aug 9th. It is now Aug 30th and after having to charge all of the cameras at least once, one of them is completely dead. It just stopped working a couple days after being fully charged. It wont even turn on, and does nothing when connected to a power cord. What total trash this system is now! Excellent sound, decent video, poor motion detection.  It barely detects 15 feet in front of a camera. The outdoor cameras randomly get some sort of light flare and record the motion, and miss actual motion such as a car driving by. The delay on recording when there is motion is a little sad. The Pro 2 has fixed this however a software update could probably do the same for these. The app is a little difficult to navigate at times. I got this on a "Deal of the Day" for $550 for the 5 camera system so price wise it is not bad. The motion detection leaves a lot to be desired.  The sound quality is excellent.  It picks up a lot and very clearly. The video quality is ok, zooming in is almost a worthless feature as it gets incredibly grainy at the slightest zoom.  It is designed for outdoor use but only comes with 1 mount for outside? Had to buy more to use outside if you dont want to use the magnet mounts that are 10x easier to steal the camera off of.
title: Poor motion detection,  good video, great sound

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Shawn M. Espinoza
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. September 26th 2018 Update: So as I mentioned in my original review (you can scroll down to read it), I mentioned how that was just a temporary review. That I would return to write a full review. Well here I am. Now, my original review, is still very accurate. I've just now have had this product for just a tad bit over a month. I'm still loving this system. In the month I've had this, I had a couple of hiccups. Mainly they were just two times when the camera wasn't connecting to the Arlo Base. I'm not sure why exactly. The first time was most likely because the base station was a little far and kind of out of view, but that original spot was never meant to be a permanent area for it. I was going to move the Arlo base station to the kitchen, on top of the cabinets. Which basically puts it central to our apartment, in terms of location. That increased the signal nicely, but the second time the camera was having an issue connecting to the base, I'm not exactly sure why. But all I did to fix it was to resync the camera to the base and it worked fine. I can manually record a live stream just fine. I can snap a photo just fine. I'm able to download videos to my device just fine. I'm able to access the camera from my desktop just fine. Mind you, I still have the original set up for the camera. Which is i used gorilla tape that can hold up to 30 pounds to the wall frame just adjacent to my apartment door, which is aluminum. I used the magnetic knob that comes with the arlo camera system so that I can easily remove the camera so that I can charge it when it needs to be charged. Now that brings me to the battery usage. I'm not really in a high traffic area, i think. I live on the fifth floor in a Queens NYC apartment building. I have one neighbor that lives adjacent to our apartment. So the camera faces away from our door towards the stairwell. So obviously it would catch recordings when they enter and leave their apartment, when i and my husband enter and leave the apartment and if anyone uses the stairwell which really isnt all that much. So in the month i've had this camera, it caught a lot of us and our neighbors entering and exiting our apartments. I'm not sure if thats really a whole lot, but the cameras battery only lasted a month. The setting i had it on was prioritize the battery and pretty much record in low quality. The quality recorded looked like dvd quality so i was happy with that. As long as i can see faces, i'm good, so i was happy with the setting i chose because i wanted to prioritize the battery life. Even choosing that setting, the battery did not last the 6 months it was advertised as on the website. Now, is this an issue? Personally no, because the last security camera i had wouldn't even give me 3 weeks, let alone a full month. Would I have liked a full 6 months out of the battery? sure! Will others have issues with the battery life? most likely. I dont have a setup where i could leave the camera plugged into an outlet, so i have to remove the camera each time i need to charge the battery. Since i'm in an apt, it's not a big issue for me personally. Also, if your gonna charge the battery and remove it from whatever setup you have, your gonna have to go into the settings and literally turn off the camera before starting your charging. since if it remains on, it'll take forever and a year to really charge. So make a note, turn off the camera and charge it up! Thats all I've used the camera for really. Just to monitor who's in front of our apt. It's worked just fine so far. I really do recommend this for apartment dwellers. I know that my sister who owns a home on Long Island has a 5 camera system and she has had no issues either with her setup. But if you feel you need that extra layer of security, I highly recommend this one camera system. Don't bother leveling up the paid services. I still use the free 7 day cloud service. It records to the cloud easily, and as long as i can review the videos within the 7 day period, I'm good to go. Remember, you can also connect a portable hard drive to the back of the arlo base to keep all the videos your camera records, so if you have like a small portable 1 terabyte harddrive connected to it, you really would't need to pay for any subscription service. This really is recommended for apartment dwellers, my suggestion. if you live in a home and depending on the setup, you may need to pay for some sort of service, but I sure dont and am happy with the free cloud service and the great option to plug in my own external drive to save all the videos. I think thats all for me now. If i see i need to make another update, i will. Original review August 24th 2018 below: The reason for my headline is because i've only had this product for about a day now. I just wanted to let you all know how this product is doing after just the first day. The setup was extremely simple. Unbox everything, connect the base station to your router via ethernet cable in a central location to where you will be placing your cameras, connect the power adaptor to the base station, install rechargeable battery into the camera (battery is already pre-charged for you before it leaves the factory), wait till you see the two left green lights on the base station, install the arlo app onto your mobile device, hit sync on the base station and arlo camera, and after a couple of updates, one for the station, and one for the cameras...your all set! this process took about 10 minutes or less. now, my personal reason for buying this one camera system is because i live in new york city and obviously i rent an apartment. i've had some issues with people leaving trash in front of my apartment door, and stealing my doormat. so i went around looking for a camera system that could work well with someone like me who lives in an apartment. a rental no less. i did find one other camera but due to an upgrade in software, it rendered it useless, so i had to return it for a refund. so i was on the search for something else i can use. this arlo pro camera system beat out a lot of the security cameras out there that pretty much are more for homes then apartments. i say this because the other cameras out there require a hardwire line to power said camera. since i live in a rental apartment, i can't go drilling holes in the door or wall. so i needed something that worked via a rechargeable battery that i can pull out and charge away from the camera. this particular setup comes with a magnetic base where the camera can attach to easily. now the base is why i chose this particular security camera, you can either install the base to the wall via screws, which i can't cuz i'd be damaging my rental...OR if you use heavy duty gorilla double sided tape that can hold items that are at least 6 pounds or greater on the wall, you can use the gorilla tape to attach the magnetic small base to the wall and than attach the camera. this was a huge game changer with security camera's available that can do those. like i said, most need to be wired, while just a select few of other cameras just need a magnetic base, but dont come with the same features like what arlo packs in. so now we're here with my setup, and once again i'll update this fully after i've installed it exactly where i wanted to. because i'm still waiting on my gorilla tape to arrive so i haven't as of yet attached it to the outside door frame of my apartment. but what i did learn is that i can have the camera pretty far from the base station. according to the manual, each camera you sync can not be more than 300 feet away from the base station, otherwise it wont connect. which means no feed cuz its too far from the base station. my apartment has a pretty crappy issue with wifi, but this base station allowed me to place the arlo pro camera two rooms away from it and still get a great feed! mind you i live in a two bedroom apartment with the base station in the living room which is the room closest to the apartment door but furthers from the other two bedrooms. i was very pleased with the connectivity it was able to reach. so basically, the cameras only connect to the arlo base station, NOT to your home wifi, thats why arlo has you connect the base station to your router wired. so if your router is too far from where you'd need to place the base station, i suggest getting a long ethernet cable so you can place the base station in a central location with ease. now since my setup isn't complete, i did leave the arlo pro camera in my living room on a shelf just so i can test the notifications i get and live feed and the event history of videos that are stored. i haven't subscribed to any of the paid tiers available, heres why. according to arlo, the free cloud service is probably fine for someone like me who lives in an apartment. it stores videos it's recorded to the cloud for the last 7 days, which is about 1 gig of storage your allotted to have free. that amount of storage is completely fine, because as it stated, i'm allowed to download any of the videos its recorded over the course of 7 days, i can share said videos to anyone as well. BUT there's another bonus for those who dont upgrade to the paid tiers, you can attach to the base station any usb external drive and tell arlo to write to the external drive you connect! i haven't had a chance to test it out, but i will do so this weekend by first simply connecting a 16GB usb stick. in the settings you have the option to allow all the videos to be recorded onto the usb stick and after it fills up, you can choose to have the base station start overwriting from the oldest video. i'll write more on this after i've had a chance to really test it out. but that feature kind of makes some of the paid tier levels moot. especially for us apartment dwellers. i mean sure some of the paid levels have some features like smart notifications and emergency 911, but with the free level, if you see someone trying to break in, you can hit the alarm which will sound a 100 decibal alarm, which i hear is very loud. may make the robbers back away, but could potentially give you enough time to call 911 on your own. of course for the camera features, there's a two way mic, so you can talk to the person on the other side. the only downside is that once you start speaking, you need to quickly toggle off the button so you can hear the other person talking....at least thats how it is on my testing. like i said i haven't been able to really test this fully. so when i make a new review i'll be sure to let you all know. i did learn that the motion sensors work the best when they pick up motion on the periphery of the sensors. rather then being activated as someone is coming head on to the camera, they work best if they see motion come from the sides of the camera. thats something i noticed that i'm sure will help some of you properly set up the camera. all in all, i'm getting the notifications nicely and so far no issues, but i'll definitely update this down the road with more details!
title: Updated Review for NYC apartment dwellers! 9/26/18

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: John Huan Vu
content: Arlo has given a solid product overall but the have cut back their features significantly causing me to consider other products. As of July 13, 2020 in Pacific Time, the email notification templates have changed in which your image preview of the alerts has been stripped. Other members who uses Arlo in the community have seen this too. Why is this significant before you purchase?  Users who get tons of email notifications. Over 90% of the time is due to the wind, a wandering cat, or a bug passing through the camera. The remaining time is when the postal worker arrives, a neighbor knocks on your door, or some suspicious. Given this, customers should not be required to review the Arlo App every time we get 10+ emails. We should be able to open our emails, quickly review and delete when appropriate. Unfortunately, Arlo has stripped this functionality and I caution all new users.
title: Changes in July 2020 brought down to 1 star

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Ale
content: These systems are sold as better quality and pricy, but the software is bare bones, basic functionality is missing. For example, the Q series cameras cannot connect to the base and trigger the alarm. They are set up using the same app, but you cannot just connect them. The Arlo forum says they are "expanding the functionality". Them the alarm scheduling only schedules start and end dates over the same day, so there is no way to schedule an alarm over midnight! The response in the Arlo forum is ludicrous. Don't be fooled by nice looks, the software quality is below cheap Chinese equivalents. Also, beware that besides some cameras, with horrendous limitations, there are no other options in peripherals, there is no door/window open sensors and such. All in all, no reason to buy.
title: Very disappointing bare bones software

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: JK
content: Original review: We bought this to add on to our existing Arlo system. The Arlo cameras work great. This one, however came with a completely dead battery. It did charge fast, but it now has half the battery life left as the other cameras that were installed 3 weeks earlier. Update: As I feared, the battery that arrived dead IS a bad battery. As I mentioned, I bought this add on camera 3 weeks after installing he rest of the system that came with 4 cameras. While 2 of the original cameras have never been charged, I’ve had to charge this camera 3 times. I fully understand that battery life may depend on how often the camera is activated, but I have 2 other cameras that get activated far more than this one, and I’ve only charged the other 2 one time each. I called Arlo customer support, and it was horrific. First, try to find their number on their website. Talk about hidden! Finally found it and called. I could barely understand the person I was talking to. She had to repeat every sentence 2 or 3 times due to a heavy accent. Finally she told me I had to change the battery setting from “optimized” to “best battery life” and if that made the battery last longer than problem solved. Of course it will make the battery last longer, but at the expense of camera quality, and by the way, it is currently set up the same way as my other 4 cameras and they don’t die like this one does! I was getting nowhere, and requesting a supervisor resulted in there were none available. There was no way Arlo was going to stand behind their product. I called Amazon support and thanks to their phenomenal support, they agreed to let me return it. Besides this glitch, I like my Arlo camera system. If I had known they do not stand behind their product, however, I would have chosen a different system.
title: Battery seems to be bad - update: the battery IS bad

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Anon
content: I purchased the Arlo Pro 5 camera system on Dec 22 2017 and requested a refund on 1/12/2018. Before trying the Arlo Pro system, I also tried out the Ring security system and the Lorextechnology.com / FLIR security system. Out of the three systems I would have to say that the Arlo Pro system was by far the worst.  Was it a surveillance system, yeah sure, but was it a security system, I would say no. In addition to purchasing the 5-camera system, I also bought 3 NETGEAR solar panels, multiple camouflage and ghillie suit skins, different length charging / connection cords and an array of different styles / angles camera mounts. I have to say that look and feel of the cameras were nice, I loved the sleek aesthetic design and I really enjoyed the strong magnet on the back of the cameras, you could easily put it on anything metal and it stayed firmly.  I also loved the ability to run anything wirelessly, wired, or through solar panels. ½ of the extra items I bought were through Wasserstein or something of that sort.  A lot of these extras were not compatible with the cameras such as extended micro USB cords, which was completely asinine, even though they were the same exact model and fit, the camera app said not compatible because it wasn’t a NETGEAR cord. My favorite feature of the entire system was the ability to trigger an audible alarm by the housing station. It was also incredibly easy to set up and link the cameras, only one camera gave me constant problems with being able to do a firmware update.  Arlo Pro was also great because they offered a 7 day free cloud recording service. 5 cameras were free and if you wanted to add more then 5, you had to pay. The phone app offered some great features that both Ring and Lorex did not such as geo-fencing, the ability to turn on and off the entire alarm system, scheduled alarm times,  but other then that the app was garbage. The app took way to long to both login and connect with the devices. If you wanted to view an immediate notification, it took at least 20 seconds before you were able to start live viewing if even at all. Now the phone app delay was just a minor issue compared to the delay of movement capturing by the camera. I spent around 15-20 hours, a few hours each day for a week comparing different angles, installing different mounts, and adjusting zones, and heights. There were a few instances such as the FEDEX guy or UPS guy delivering packages to my house, only one of the three cameras facing the front of the house captured the delivery and it was only the very tail end of a person walking out of my drive way. The only reason I knew it was a delivery guy was because the camera caught the tail end of the delivery FEDEX truck pulling in my driveway. There were also several instances of family members pulling in and out of the driveway or walking up to the front door, which either caught only a few seconds exiting the view of the camera or did not capture it at all. One of the cameras view a side of my house and partially shows my neighbor’s driveway, it is a vacation property, which is rarely ever used, and my neighbor has asked me to keep an eye on it for suspicious activity. He has a bi weekly lawn service which comes, the cameras did not even capture a huge landscaping truck with 4 guys working in the yard until one of them was leaf blowing about ½ in my yard … wtf. This is totally unacceptable as a security camera system and was the main reason I returned them… well because they don’t work. The night vision and IR lights on the camera are extremely terrible; it was basically pointless to even check notifications or live views on the camera at night. Every night for the week I went outside with my ladder to mess with different angles. The IR emitted such a strong reflection that it drowned out a lot of the images. The only way night vision was even somewhat effective was in an open view with no trees, walls, cars, or anything to reflect. Even while I was walking up to the cameras you could barely make out any distinguishing features to tell people apart. It was just a huge white blur, even worse, right on top of the camera; it looked as if you were a ghost.  If you wanted to look at multiple cameras at night time, you also better not have them pointed in the same facing direction because the night vision emitted an incredibly powerful white blur to the other cameras. The NETGEAR solar panels were also not very good, it never registered on the app as being connected unless there was an absolute direct sun light beaming on it, not even partially, as the batteries continued to lose percentage. If you live in a densely wooded property as I do, this could be a problem. Overall I felt this entire system was incredibly expensive for what it offered, it was basically a toy camera system. There was no practical application for the entire system unless you are happy with just viewing your property during the day from time to time. Notifications rarely prompted immediate viewing and capturing events rarely happened period.  Nighttime use was… useless. I would not recommend the Arlo Pro system to anyone. However even though I have gone through Ring and Lorex systems too, I cannot justify trying out the Nest system based on their absurd cloud recording fees. Ring has been the best experience I’ve had so far and they have reached out to me several times for a bad review / experience that I had with them.  Even though there was some technical oversight, I will be giving Ring another try as their entire system was overall much better. I took off one star for the expensive price, the 2nd star for the inability to properly detect motion, 3rd star for the useless night vision, and the 4th star for a terrible phone app and the ability to use third party accessories. There is a lot of potential and the idea of the system is great, but it should've never been released as is. It needs a ton of improvements for it to be worth the price they ask.
title: The Good, the Bad, and the UGLY!!! Basically a TOY camera system, Day time surveillance use only.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: TC
content: Sorely disappointed. I was really hoping the camera would perform better given some of the stellar reviews online and the fact that the compact wireless camera appeared to fit our needs perfectly!!! While the camera design is sleek we were disappointed by performance right from the jump.  First off having a cumbersome base station was inconvenient to say the least! In addition, at first boot the firmware on both the camera and base station required updating and the camera was worthless for an hour as it could not re-connect to the base station.  This prevented any 'live' content feeds and prevented setup.  Once it was up and running there was no indication of poor connectivity, but the latency to record was ridiculous! I was able to take camera from proposed placement location and walk all the way through the house to bedroom prior to camera being able to initiate recording feature. This rendered the camera effectively useless! It could easily be taken from premises and miss any important content! I eventually returned it the same day. Never got a handle on battery life as the camera was not performing long enough before return. I will say the quality of the picture was as expected for a 720p.  We ended up with a nest outdoor and are much happier.
title: Great Design but performance was a painful disappointment!!!!

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Grover517
content: Intended use - Outside driveway/front entry monitor. Edit:  Fast forward about a year from original purchase and although the hardware review below remains basically the same, I have lowered my star rating from 2 to 1 solely based on the most recent direction Arlo has taken in regards to their smartphone apps functionality.  Arlo has basically let it's existing user base know that they view the Arlo system more as a "baby monitor" setup than a true security system by rolling out a software update that is so drastic of a change, it has cripiled a system that used to be pretty darn good.  The latest update is probably the most drastic and bug ridden user interfaces I personally have ever seen from ANY company and even in the face of thousands of critical reviews from their existing user base on their own community board, Arlo not only refuses to roll back the update but also is basically ignoring those same customers concerns.  Basically, Arlo has said, "Take it or leave it".  Critical info that used to be available "at a glance" now is buried within menus requiring a LOT more user interaction and time to find what you need.  Video streaming and playback used to be basically "auto play" but now requires multiple touches as well to play back and stop.  Notifications now are much slower, sometimes 15-20 minutes behind the detected activity and just configuring the system in general is much more difficult due to the shifting of numerous settings among different menus.  So if your plans are to depend on an Arlo system to either be your primary or a supplement to an existing security system, I can no longer recommend Arlo as a good choice. The setup was easy, and the optional wall/ceiling mount installation was as well.  I mounted the camera about 15 ft above the entry and have it pointing down at the front yard/driveway/front walkway to get as wide a view as possible.  It was also mounted that high to keep it from being stolen or otherwise tampered with.  And although the specs say it should work from that distance, it has major issues, at least in our setup. Upon first installation, the video/audio from the camera was impressive (first picture below) and was very encouraged that I had found my solution.  Motion detection at default settings were excellent and worked up to 30 ft away.  So much so, that I needed to turn down the sensitivity a bit to keep from getting a lot of false detections.  However, once it got dark I was extremely disappointed.  Although the motion detection still worked at the same distances, the IR illumination/low light performance of the camera in an outside setting was utterly useless. We live in a city with street lights, and one sits in front of our next door neighbor.  With just available light from that street light,  which is more than enough to see things on the ground in our yard and driveway, I got an all black picture.  I am reading online that the IR distance on these cameras are 20 ft +/- but I am not getting anywhere near that outside. Not until I climbed back up on the ladder and got within about 5 ft of the camera, did I see ANYTHING.  Since we also have a 100w front porch LED as well as a 300w motion sensing flood mounted approx. 10 ft. below the camera placement and when on, basically light up the entire front property to almost daylight proportions.  You would think that turning them on would help immensely, right?  Sadly, no.  With both the front porch light and floods on, I could barely make out a ghostly glow from those lights along the lower porch roofline.  (picture 2 below).
