product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Charlie Colquhoun
content: I really like my wireless two camera Arlo Pro setup. After playing with the motion detection settings I seem to have the right balance of video clips being picked up from activity around our urban area town house (e.g. mail/shipment deliveries, my direct neighbor walking dog along our back shared path, people walking by our entrance etc). It is very easy to setup and sync. For installation and to avoid the hassle of drilling into the exterior stucco wall,  I purchased the suction cup mounts (and skins in black) separately from Wassertein and easily set the cameras up on the outside of our windows that look down over our front entrance and backyard. The suction cups are really incredibly strong and held up nicely during a recent heavy rain and wind storm. I did later add tethers for secondary piece of mind and cosmetics (Cosmos ® 2 PCS 24 Inch Black Color Stainless Steel Tether Lanyard Wire Coated in Soft Plastic for Gopro)  The rechargeable batteries on the pro last me about a 3-4 weeks right now (based on motion detection settings and how often you look at a live feed).  I am happy and content with that. You can add users to the app/web/cloud recordings and alerts, so my wife also can see activity and use the system. We can even trigger the 100 decibel siren on the pro base unit if we needed to from the app if we see suspicious activity and we are away. I am looking forward to a solar drip plug in charging unit which is rumoured to be in the works from the Arlo discussion boards, which would be a nice to have.
title: Great product, great design, great app!

author: C. v bick
content: I wanted to like Arlo so bad, because setting it up was so easy and the wireless camera looks and sounds great, but they really need to do more QA. There are too many hardware and software problems. I work in tech and have specifically worked with wireless communicators. After working through multiple hardware and software issues (managing to avoid customer service which I've heard is terrible.)  I got the system to work. 20 minutes after placing the camera I find out that the camera is "offline." They don't even have it set up so that you get a notification if a camera goes down. So I went through troubleshooting and managed to get it working again. 20 minutes later, camera goes offline I get it to work and not work and then fail a few minutes later about 3Xs before I came to the conclusion that the camera cannot stay connected to the base station some 15 feet away...I live in a small condo I don't see how these would work for anybody if they don't work for my tiny place. My hope is that something is defective and I can get it working after replacing. I'll post and update.
title: I wanted to like Arlo so bad!

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Scott P.
content: The Arlo Pro is a great camera system. Setup was extremely easy and I'm generally happy with the sensitivity, which was the main thing I was worried about after reading other reviews. We have it setup at a 45 degree angle to our front door in a narrow entry area, and it picks up people within a second or so as long as they aren't sprinting to our front door. The ability to plug in an external hard drive to get local copies of the video is a good feature that I didn't see any many other cameras of this type. That + the free 7 days of rolling cloud coverage means that you won't need to upgrade to a paid subscription unless you really want to. I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because I really think it needs 1080p to be get viable shots of peoples faces as they cross the field of view. I've also had a 1-2 videos that show a few seconds of motion and then everything holds still and I can only hear audio. Could be a connection issue, and time will tell whether this is a recurring problem or not.
title: Overall a good system, but resolution could be improved.

author: Alaina Nash
content: I've had the camera's about a week now.  I have been playing with them and their capabilities.  Getting used to the different settings and how they respond has taken some time but I now know how to use them for my situation. I mounted one on the porch and in 6 short days I ran the battery completely down.  Not because it was an issue but I wanted to see what happens when I run it with Audio and motion detected.  Since the wind blows and the birds chirp I had nearly constant video in 4min 58 second clips which was consistent for that setting. My inside camera were still at 92% after a week but the porch was down to 20%.  Of course I changed the settings and the battery is lasting much longer. The audio is clean and crisp.  Using the mike the speakers still have something to be desired and volume is low but works. Charging a battery from 20% to full took less than an hour. The app is awesome as is the website. You get your cameras up, you can go live, manually record, check systems status and a bunch more.  You can power off a camera in the app also. Custom modes lets you build different rules to meet your varying needs. I have one the excludes the porch camera during the day and one that only arms the porch camera at night. If you set the video quality to HD it i amazing.  Set it to balanced and it is still awesome but distance (200 ft.) is a little fuzzy but very view able. The Geofencing works great on Android.  I can set the mode and view my cameras from anywhere. Adding cameras to the base station is so super simple.  NetGear got this right. Now coupled with my monitored alarm systems separate from Arlo the Cameras will record for cops to see. The only reason it didn't get 5 stars was the speaker sound and volume.  I'm sure that will be the next improvement.
title: Great Camera System

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: jt
content: Pro:  If you have an area of your home or business (like a side or back door) that is rarely used, but needs a motion alert camera on it just in case... this is a viable camera choice.  Also good for just watching some remote area in real-time.  Excellent quality video.  Might work well as an outside front door camera pointed in such a way that it only alerts when someone is right at your door. Con:  Terrible for high motion areas.  It will send you an email every time something moves.  No way to turn configure it otherwise.  Motion detection is only configurable from 0% to 100%. No way to customize the alert zone, just alert sensitivity.  If motion alert is set at 80% sensitivity, anything moves you get an alert.  So.. if you have it in a general area of your home or business where there is regular traffic.. you going to get hundreds of email every day.  Set sensitivity to 0% (I'm guessing this means 'OFF'), then you just have a real-time remote viewing camera.  There is no sound (like breaking window) alert option.  Also..  Packaging is designed for store shelf merchandising.  Way over packaged for mail order.  Each camera is a packaged in a ton of packaging.  Almost filled up my trash can after unboxed.  A lot of stuff to throw in the land file or recycling center. Glad I did not buy a 4 camera kit.
title: Probably not the way to go for most security camera installs

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Cape Dory Sailor
content: I had a problem initially setting up an account that many other people complain of, but I was able to work around it. Once the account was setup, adjusting everything just the way I wanted it was a 15 minute affair. Not having to run any wires at all makes this so much easier to set up and use. I've purchased two $200 wired/DVR type systems that I have never installed, because even after weeks of playing with the software, I could never get them to work properly. This is not the case with the Arlo Pro: it could not be easier, and it works perfectly every time. It records every time there is motion, those recordings are on the cloud every time, the quality is great every time, and I get an email alert every time. Yes, this is arguably one of the most expensive security camera systems on the market, but it is absolutely worth it for the ease of use. Also, if you have your router and cable modem on a UPS, you effectively have a system that will work even if someone cuts the power. That kind of peace of mind is worth far more than the cost of these cameras. I started with two cameras, but am already looking forward to adding another. If you've tried any other type of security camera system, you'll likely agree the price is worth every penny.
title: Absolutely fantastic compared to wired counterparts

The re-chargeable battery surely does beat buying expensive lithium batteries for the regular camera.  However, the battery runs down very quickly. For example, charged it to 100% in the morning, after a little more than 24hrs, the remaining charge is down to 65%; this is after reducing motion sensitivity to 50% so that I don't get hundreds of recordings of every car that drives by.  Most of the time, the yellow light indicates that it is not close enough to base station, and frequently a message is indicates that it is offline. When camera used outside with temperature in 30's, it has to warm up before it will re-charge the battery.  I'm still contemplating buying another re-chargeable camera...

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: ThadCaper
content: Arlo Pro Cameras are great, though the app and system need a few tweaks to catch up. I haven’t found a way for system to alert me to power or internet outages as of yet, which should obviously be an option. It was not intuitive to find where to adjust the length of video clips or sensitivity of motion detection – important settings that everyone will need that are buried in settings layers. Additionally, I needed to contact support for one of my cameras and was given a 35-50 minute estimated wait time, and when I went the email route, it took three days for support to respond.  Will eventually be a great system I’m sure with a few refinements. Updated 1/11:  Emailed support asking how to enable option to be alerted when the system loses internet or power, and they shared it's not technically possible, though there are many cloud based services that can alert users when a connection is lost (Alarm.com, various thermostats and other home monitoring services, etc.)  The solution is simple – if a device hasn’t checked in with the cloud server after a certain number of seconds, then the server sends an alert letting the user know their device has lost connection.  That allows for the user to check other systems to see if there’s an intruder who has cut the internet, cut the power, turned off the base station, or just a power outage.  I’m disappointed to learn after spending a lot of money on the system that this isn’t already in place, and that support seems to think this technology isn’t available. Also disappointed at how long it takes support to respond to messages.
title: Great Cameras, Though System, App and Support Need Refinements

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: kmk
content: READ THIS IF YOU DON'T WANT TO INSTALL THIS OUTSIDE BUT YOU STILL WANT TO MONITOR THE OUTDOORS. > I don't have a good place to install my camera for the front because I don't want the camera to be visible to others (no one else has a camera that is visible to me on their front of their houses in our neighborhood). > I also don't want to put in holes in my siding or trim. > I don't want the risk of having this expensive camera stolen (the one possibly place I may put is about 7' - 8' high only, not  higher). I thought I would have decided on a place to install this in the front and took a chance and ordered this set anyways. Currently, the cameras are on the window sill looking out. They are not hardly obvious from the outside, which is what I prefer. BUT, that means, there is ONLY LIVE viewing now. I have to turn off motion and audio detection because obviously it won't work for outside through the window. It only picks up noise and motion inside which is not what I want because the camera is pointing out anyways. So, I have this expensive camera set with still has a great option of being able to view from my smartphone from anywhere and if I happen to see anything unusual LIVE, I can do a manual recording. And I have the speaker function also. But that's it. It's a bit frustrating that I can't use motion or audio and maybe I should look around at another security system instead with the smartphone interface also, and wireless. And for live nighttime viewing, I have to have the night vision set to off or else nothing can be seen out through the glass. It only reflects the camera lights from the glass. When the night vision is off, I can see outside as if it was live. Yes, it is dark but can still make out figures and cars. When there are house lights on outside, you can see more. At least it is something. I was considering getting the suction holders (from a different brand) on the windows for the outdoors that is designed to work with these cameras, which I may try. However, since the only place I would install this will be installed at most about 7-1/2' high, near an entrance under an overhang, there is still a chance it could be stolen. But it would be next to a window and no way to sneak up behind the camera in that location anyways without being recorded. But I am concerned with the lag-time that occurs with these cameras. However, these cameras are still great for what they can do. product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: gtf2859
content: This camera has some good and bad points, which I will clear up here.  First of all, if you are not very handy with some tools or computer literate, don't buy this.  Get a pro to instal a regular one.  This is not for people who don't want to do hours of work. After you install it, it works well. If you are average with a computer it will take you about a half hour to install the software and set up your phone.  For me, it took an hour.  As usual, the user manual for these electronics don't come with the item, just a basic set up guide.  You have to go online to download a lengthy 100 page manual to understand everything this camera can do.  And it does many things.  For the money you pay, this manual should be in the box. The company is deceptive on several issues, which I found to be outright lies.  They claim you just take off the camera from it's mount to recharge the battery.  Yeah, get up on a ladder every 2-3 months and take the camera down to recharge it.  I don't think so.  If you read the manual, it says  the battery will only need recharging every 3-4 months for normal use.  That's a lie.  Using it on the factory settings, the battery went down to 65 % after one month. At that rate, it will only last 2- 3 months max.  And I have very little traffic where I put it up in front of my door.  I have no kids, and the sensor was only going off a few times a day when my wife or I went in and out, or a delivery person came.  The manual states they you can change the power mode to give you longer battery life.  Well the only way to do that is to reduce your video resolution.  Now who wants to buy a camera to lessen the image ?  And they state that it only takes about 2.5 hours to charge a battery that is down to 0.  This is a lie.  My battery was down to 65 %, and it took 4 hours and 5 minutes to charge it to 100 %.  That means if your battery was down to 0, it would take you over 8 hours to charge that battery, 8 hours you have no camera outside, and you have to remember to put it back.  This is nonsense !  I can understand some of the specifications to be a little off, but when they are this off, you know they deliberately lied about this stuff to make it seem like it's so easy and fast to recharge the battery.  The whole battery aspect is ridiculous.  It works, if you want to take the maintenance time to do everything every 2-3 months.  Who has time for this ?  Maybe if you are retired with nothing to do. The physical design of the camera is ridiculous.  They only enclose one magnetic mounting disc, which can work for certain areas. This will work with drilling as little as one small hole for one screw. And it does work well.  But it you want more options, like to have it angled more down or to the side, it won't work.  Now you have to buy a special screw on mount, which the camera has a threaded hole for.  You can get them for as little as $5.00 online, but you'll wait weeks for it, unless you want to pay more.  Be prepared to drill 3 holes for that mount.  Now for the nightmares.  Since the battery life is horrible, and you won't want to go outside and stand on your ladder to remove the camera every 2-3 months to bring it in to recharge the battery, you need to buy another part - the optional AC charging cord.  BTW, do not order the one from Weinstein, for some reason people say it doesn't work.  Get the 20' one from Panda.  It will cost you about $16.00.  Again, this should have been included in the box. If you are selling a do it yourself camera, everything you might need should be in the box.  I didn't see one from Arlo, I don't know why.  I did read that when they came out with the camera, they didn't even have the AC cord.  Really?  They made an AC adaptor cord hole for it, but didn't include the cord or even make one.  That came many months later.  Now when you plug this cord in, you will see that you can't use the better mounting bracket, the hole for the screw mounting unit is right next to the AC jack.  Impossible to use both.  Whoever designed that should be fired.  Then, if you use the included magnetic mount, you will see that you can't angle the camera very downward, the way you need it, because the AC cord gets in the way with the mounting bracket.  Your camera will probably be too high.  I wanted mine pointed more down in front of my door, and I can't get the area right in front of the door anymore.  Absolute stupidity on this manufacturer.  The AC cord hole should have been put on the top or the side, it gets in the way of any of the optional accessories that you need. Now for more aggravation.  When I ordered the AC cord, I though all I would have to do is drill a small 1/4 hole through the top of the door frame, to thread the cord inside my door, and about 8 feet to an outlet. I measured the door frame at almost 6" deep.  What I thought would be a 15 minute task wound up taking me over 3 hours of work.  One end of the cord is a mini USB, which is a right angle plug.  I would need to drill a one inch hole to get that through. The other end is a standard USB cord, which I only needed a 5/8 " hole to thread through.  In order to drill this through an average 6" door frame, you need to use a 1/4" wide 12" long drill bit, which most homeowners won't have.  Don't get anything bigger to make your initial hole, the drill will go wild on you.  Unfortunately, my long bit was old and not very sharp, and there was metal strips in two layers of the frame.  To me, it just looked like wood frame, an easy drill with even an old bit.  I was there drilling for 5 minutes and couldn't get through the metal.  Luckily I have a drill bit sharpener, which most homeowners won't have, and I had to sharpen it 4 times to get the big through.  I had sweat running in my eyes from all of this.  It was only about 80 degrees in Florida at the time. Then, you have to drill open each side from the 1/4" inch to 5/8", using each size bit at a time, on each side of the door, otherwise your drill will go wild in the hole.  For the 5/8' bit, which I had never used, I had to switch drills to a hammer drill, because my standard electric one did not accept the 1/2" shank that comes with the 5/8" bit.  Just more aggravation.  Most homeowners won't have that type of hammer drill.  Then I had to drill out each side so many times to fish that USB cord through, using a metal hanger with tape to fish it through.  Yeah, it  sounds easy, but I'm handy, not a contractor.  It took hours of labor to do all of this.  Then you have to use a staple gun - use the rounded staples, to tack it down your door frame.  Be carefull, the wire is a flat wire, which barely fits in the rounded staple, it looks better.  It's easy to send the staple through the wire, which can damage your wire.  I did this once, but luckily it didn't affect the wire. Better to get coax plastic brackets that come with nails to hang the wire around the frame .  Just pre drill the holes to make it easier to install. Then hammer them in. Finally, you'll need a tube of chaulk or wood filler to fill up that big hole in the door or window frame.  Than paint it when it dries. The cord works, constantly charging the battery, but as you can see, this was a long tedious project. The average home owner or senior won't want to deal with all of this.  If you are not handy and will to work hours at this, don't buy this camera.  Otherwise, the camera works well.
title: This camera works, but is poorly designed

I like the "live" mode where live video/sound is streamed directly to my phone... One thing I found weird is that in order to "speak" I have to press down the microphone icon and then "release" to listen to the sound again (operates like "push to talk" feature). I haven't yet figured out how to enable longer video captures than default 10 seconds, but every feature seems to work so far.  Video quality is not perfect but not bad either.  I will definitely be adding more cameras to the system soon.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: -mike-
content: I purchased my Arlo Pro System for a second vacation home that I recently acquired.  In virtually all respects the Arlo System is one of the best technical products  have ever purchased.  It was very easy to set up, both the Base Station and the 4 Pro Cameras I purchased, including the following steps: access to the Internet through my existing Modem/Router; connection of the 4 Pro Cameras to the Arlo Base Station; updating the firmware for both the Base Station and the cameras; installation of the Arlo iPhone app; and learning to use the well-developed Arlo iPhone app to modify the system and camera settings to fit my personal preferences.  The system provides a wealth of options and features which can be accessed, turned on/off, and personalized with ease.  However, the default system settings work very well right out of the box.  Whether you're considering a single Camera or up to five Cameras this is an outstanding video security system that delivers exactly what it promises.  You can start with a single camera and add up to four additional cameras at any time, either one-at-a-time or as a group, as your needs change.  A lifetime "basic" cloud-based storage system for up to 5 cameras and 7 days of rolling storage is included in the package at no additional cost.  You can also plug a USB Memory Stick into the Arlo Base Station to capture all 'motion-triggered' video clips for long-term local retention.  Longer cloud storage options are also available at additional monthly cost if that better fits you needs.  The only negative I observed is that, while the sound capture function does work, it is limited in terms of volume and could certainly be improved.  Bottom Line:  5 Stars!!  -mike-
title: Not Perfect, But Really a Great Product!

author: Jeff Ballard
content: I have 5 regular Arlo's and several Pro units.  Of the 8 cameras I have, 3 have serious issues.  Battery depletes after a few days; won't stay pared to the base unit after a few days; etc.. Have rotated the units around and the problems remain with the troubled devices.  Will return for warranty repair.  On the up side, those cameras which work well are otherwise flawless except for the limited IR light range (night lighting).  Respectible considering these are wireless/battery operated. ALSO- WTH- software doesn't allow you to 'mask' the motion detection; meaning you can bring up the camera image and block out part of the image for the motion detection to ignore, i.e., like a waving flag or tree, while keeping motion active for the rest of the picture.  STANDARD FEATURE with practically every other camera (AND WOULD SAVE BATTERY LIFE).  Just abysmal that Netgear devotes so little to it's software development and product quality.  Would return these if I still could.
title: Junk software, OK cameras for those that work.

author: Skylane
content: Well, I was excited to get the Arlo Pro 5 camera system... as it was totally wireless! I am techie, so I was able to figure out the install (but it took more time than expected). I was first disappointed with the recording lag time, from when motion-was-detected to when recording actually starting... I was further disappointed that; when it was obvious there was still motion... it stops recording (not capturing it all of the motion). Then, I started having intermittent motion-detection issues with my most active camera... it has stopped recording any motion, 3 times in 30 days, only working again after I (reboot) remove the battery & replace it in the camera. I was further disappointed that; when I tried to "chat" online with support, it never would connect... so, when I called support... there was an unusual lengthy wait (with no prompts suggesting what the hold time would be) for a support person. I was further disappointed that; the support person (who's first language clearly was not English) had trouble understanding me and put me on hold many times... the script she was using, clearly was not correct for my issue. After 34 minutes, and coming back, after the last being-put-on-hold... she finally decided to replace the camera, and sent me an RMA email. Imagine my surprise when when I read I have to send them the defective camera (AT MY EXPENSE) before they will send me a replacement camera!!! So, I am going to have to pay shipping on a defective camera (I pay for Prime so I don't pay shipping costs, but I guess I will have to anyway!)... based on my experience (so far), I doubt I'll ever purchase another NETGEAR product. You may also want to think twice!
title: Think twice before you buy NETGEAR

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Audra long
content: We are thrilled with the Arlo as a Nanny Cam.  The 720p is crisp and clear.  Streaming and downloading videos is extremely quick and easy.  I added a USB hard drive to the system in less than 30 seconds - all automatic.  We are very, very happy with the system and after agonizing over all the options out there - this is the best. For me, I LOVE that it is battery operated.  I had thought and considered the various wired cameras - that would have been a HUGE mistake.  I have one camera in a top-back corner of a kids room - impossible with a corded setup (or permanent and involving an electrician).  I also like the idea of moving them around wherever I want - not where there are outlets and ways i can hide the cord..  These are perfect.  I put one in a higher up window facing out.  It looks nice, doesn't look weird, and no dangling cord that would make it look completely idiotic.  And if you just want a cord, these work fine with cords, too.  It's just that it's not necessary. Second, I love that they download to a central USB hard drive, not separate SD cards that would take a while to go in/out of.  That would be annoying.  This is not. I should address some negative reviews that had held me back: 1) this is not a security system (truly).  It will work as one, kind of.  I can set the system to alarm noisily and notify me for movement or sound.  But at the end of the day, wifi can be easily broken by a tech savvy thief, and if I'm not paying attention, no one calls the police.  There aren't the typical window break / door open alarms.  It's not meant to be that.  It can work as one - again relying on YOU to call the police - but it wouldn't be my first choice. 2) More on the "not a security system...really" aspect-- If the camera has to stand up in court to identify a face, I would want a higher resolution (or even more cameras to hit things closer up.  Nonetheless, I see faces, facial expressions, who people are clearly.  But in court or with night vision...probably not. 3) This could work as a baby monitor easily, but you'd be streaming from your phone constantly.  But it works that way and I've done that while I was doing side work in the garage. 4) Talking through the camera to people is OK, but it's not like FaceTime or a cell phone call.  But really, why are people complaining about this? It works well for what it is - you can talk in, but holding a conversation is best over a phone! A huge win.

author: D Stone
content: I recently purchased and installed an Arlo Pro.  After reading about nearly every competitive product available I decided to buy an Arlo Pro system.  Why?  After researching security cameras, Arlo Pro seemed to be the best value for the dollar. Here are the details:  Arlo Pro has a FREE account option with no monthly fees.  Rechargeable battery? Check.  Water and weather proof?  Arlo is working fine so far in the weird Minnesota winter. Works well in the dark?  You betcha!  Arlo Pro has a good microphone and the speaker also is decent, too. Multiple resolution settings are available which help to manage file sizes.  The battery life seems very good so far as well; Arlo Pro has been on the job for six days and the battery still shows 100%.  I could go on and on with all sorts of details, but they'd all be quite positive. If you're wondering about the set up experience that was a breeze too.  I think it took about as long to unbox Arlo Pro as it did to set up and configure. A couple of firmware updates were needed and that was super simple too; just a few button clicks and viola! I mounted my Arlo Pro under the overhang near my front door and about 10' off the ground, which took about 15 minutes.  While the mounting was simple it was the most difficult part of my Arlo Pro install...screws can be hard to find when dropped in the snow!  After operating Arlo Pro for one day I did tinker with some of the settings, including recording time and turning off email notifications which were sent every time the camera detected motion and captured video. In summary, I can say that Arlo Pro is a system that I would recommend to my friends without hesitation. If you're looking for a security camera system please do look carefully at all the options available; my guess is that you'll also conclude Arlo Pro is the best option available. Update 1-4/17:  I have configured my camera to record 30 seconds of video and it has been installed since December 20, 2016.  Given the current batter level, I am projecting the battery to last about 8-9 weeks between charges in the winter weather; I was projecting up to 25 weeks of battery life with the default 10 second recording per event.  Also, the temperature last night at 9:51 p.m. was about 4 degrees F and the camera was working fine.  This morning however, the ambient air temp was well below 0 and the Arlo app was telling me, "Your camera needs to warm up before you can use it."  At 9:45 a.m. the temperature is still -6 and with the morning sun shining on the camera body it's now warm enough to work again.  Impressive.
title: Looking for a great security camera? Look no further!

author: Morton
content: I purchased the Arlo, along with other security measures, in response to two burglaries in quick succession. We've been using it for almost two months now and it has provided us with greater peace of mind - when it works. Batteries are about half-drained after two months of motion sensor-only use which is what I expected after reading reviews; have not yet recharged the batteries to see what the life is like after its first non-factory charge. Pros: *System easy to set-up and install *Easy to link others to your account to help you monitor *Motion sensors work pretty well - best when you follow the instructions to capture motion moving across the camera's field of view *Affordable cloud storage plans - have been using the free plan and it's more than enough storage for our needs Cons: *Alarm nor two-way audio on cameras is very loud; have to be within 4-5 feet to hear the audio coming from the camera if outside *Motion detection and night vision will not work through a window - wish I would have known this ahead of time! *Constant issues with the devices not being connected; not an issue with my wifi. Tried firmware updates on the cameras and base station. No rhyme or reason as to when it disconnects or why. I consider myself pretty tech savvy and I didn't find the help forums to be all that helpful.
title: Pros Only Slightly Outweigh Cons

author: Justacontributor
content: The keys to this type of device from my perspective include: 1) battery life 2) image quality 3) software 4) ease of everything In short, Netgear absolutely nailed each of these 4 items.  Keep in mind that these are not commercial devices.  With that said, these are far from IP toys. For example, the software functionality is comprehensive providing many features without useless bells and whistles.  This is supplemented with a very natural format for navigating both the app and web interfaces without needing any expertise. The battery durability has been exceptional, especially in frigid winter temperatures. Image quality can be adjusted between Good/Better/Best.  I run Best and have not had excessive battery drain. Lastly, the primary reason most folks would be attracted to this product is that setup should be relatively easy.  And, yes, setup is extraordinarily simple.
title: the software functionality is comprehensive providing many features without useless bells and whistles

author: Nsiddons
content: This was my first Arlo system I wanted to get 1 camera so if I hated it, it wasn't too big of a loss. Well, I love it and have ordered more cameras and even a system for my office. Quick and easy setup except for the first firmware update I have to grab my laptop cause the iPad kept failing. Easy to mount the camera although I don't trust the magnetic mount so I bought the screw type mount. The base is way smaller than I expected. I like the way it can save to the cloud and to a USB HD, I have yet to try this feature but I will be putting the USB drive on today once the other 4 cameras I ordered arrive. I love that there's an app my Apple TVs, iPad, and iPhone and a web login for my Mac. But I had to use a ton of emails so it didn't sign out the other devices. Some people are gonna ask why do you need multiple devices, a situation is brewing on the camera and you don't want to miss it but have to switch devices, it takes time to sign on and kicks you off. I can think of many other situations. But this is Netgear software update so I still give Arlo 5 stars.
title: Best cloud security system

author: EPaul
content: DO NOT BUY THIS SYSTEM before reading this review.  After using my system for about 6 months, I realized this product was causing internet outages by interfering with the wifi signal of my wireless router (which it needs to be connected to of course).  I had a technician come out and show me exactly how it was interfering (through the wifi channels).  When he manually changed my router's channel, it all started working perfectly.  Here's the problem...any time you have a power outage, your router will reset to the default channel, same as the Arlo system.  So every time there's a power outage, they'll both use the same channel and you'll get MAJOR internet outages and decreased reception for all devices connected to your wifi.  I did some research and this is a VERY COMMON problem with this item.  What's worse, Arlo wants to charge people for customer support over 90 days out.  INSANE!!!!  Typical warranty is 1 to 2 years, yet NETGEAR wants to get away with 3 months.  Why buy a product that has major complications from a company that doesn't appreciate its customers.
title: DO NOT BUY until you read this!!!

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: MinisterofDOOM
content: After a little over 2 weeks with 3 Arlo Pro cameras, I have to say I do not trust these cameras to do their job and protect my property.  These cameras promise a lot of versatility and offer some great features.  If they worked as intented, they would be phenomenal.  The issue is that they very very rarely work as intended.  I repeatedly encounter significant issues that render the cameras nearly useless for their intended purpose (on-event-triggered recording and video monitoring of my property). I'm going to start with the issues I'm encountering, but I WILL follow up with what I like about these cameras (which is still certainly a strong list).  I should also clarify that I'm an Android phone user, so any app issues may be specific to the Android version; I can't say for sure if they also apply to the iPhone version. Firstly: The geofencing feature is completely buggy and barely functional.  I will be sitting on my couch with my phone in my hand and over a 5 minute period, the geofencing will change from Home to Away mode several times.  I have not moved.  My phone's connectivity and location detection settings have not changed.  But the geofencing keeps switching modes.  This is extremely frustrating and completely breaks the cameras usefulness as it will change the event detection settings from what they should be based on my location.  Fortunately, I do not have geofencing freak out when I'm NOT at home (e.g. when actually away, the cameras stay in Away mode) which is at least a sort of safe fail mode.  But it's still broken and not performing as advertised. Secondly: I'm being frustrated with a completely incomprehensible PERSISTENT notification from the Arlo app that tells me that "You are not connected to the Internet."  Not only does this notification fail to explain WHAT is not connected to the internet (my phone?  The base station?  One or more of the cameras?  All of the above?), but it is also completely inaccurate.  Every single time this notification has appeared,  I have been able to launch the app, connect to my cameras, and view to my heart's content.  But making it even MORE irritating is the fact that this notification can NEVER be cleared.  Even once whatever connectivity issue the app thinks it detected is clearly resolved, it persists.  The ONLY WAY TO CLEAR IT IS TO FORCE CLOSE THE ARLO APP.  This is so broken it's insane.  Why is this notification persistent at all?  None of the others are?  It might make sense if the notification was actually useful, but it has never EVER been useful.  EVER.  And I've seen it dozens upon dozens of times.  In two weeks. Thirdly: exacerbating the irritation of the broken geofencing and nonsense "not connected to the Internet" issues is the app's lack of granular notification controls.  ALL notifications from the app, be they system, event/recording alerts, geofencing alerts, mode changes, or ANYTHING, all use the same notification tone and icon.  This means that thanks to the truly insane number of useless geofencing and "not connected to the internet" alerts I see, I basically don't pay attention to notifications from the app anymore.  Because I get easily tenfold more nonsense broken-feature-triggered alerts than actually camera event alerts. Particularly in light of the excellent nested-condition mode and alerting configuration options within this app (more on that when I discuss what I like about these cameras), it seems insane to me that there's no way to tie separate notification sounds to different alerts or modes as well as to different system notifications (or to at least separate system notifications from event notifications). Fourthly: Also on the subject of notifications, the Event Detection notifications are completely inconsistent in their clickability.  Sometimes I'll get a notification that a camera has detected motion and, upon tapping it, be taking to the log-in screen of the app and then the recording for that event.  Other times, tapping the notification does absolutely nothing, and I have to launch the application manually and then find the event in the list manually.  How is this kind of inconsistent behavior even possible?  So spectacularly broken. Fifth: These cameras and their software lack detection zones (e.g. the ability to select areas of the camera's overall view to either include in or remove from motion detection).  This means that you have to be very careful how you aim them (especially when outdoors) or you will get a lot of false positive alerts on motion detection.  Each of my cameras has in its view either trees or hedges.  I have had to do a lot of tweaking on motion sensitivity, but there's no way to eliminate all false positives without reducing detection so far that REAL positives are missed.  Having the ability to block out foot-traffic areas of the cameras view from the background for motion detection would make these cameras much more dependable as event-triggered devices (which is the only way they operate; due to the battery powered nature, there's no continual record mode--even when on USB power). And lastly: The Arlo app scales from fairly responsive to completely useless.  Sometimes, I can launch the app and quickly jump into any live camera view or alerted camera view.  Other times, I am greeted with nothing more than a spinning "loading" circle.  There's now way to force a "retry" and since the app runs in the background, the only way to fix this is to force close and try again, hoping you have better luck.  When viewing an alert in urgent circumstances, this is hardly ideal.  It's also frustration compounding in a very special kind of way when the Geofencing starts freaking out, and I attempt to launch the app to see what's going on, only to be greeted with an endlessly spinning circle.  Broken compounded with broken. Now, as to what I like: The programmability of alerting, detection, and recording is exemplary.  You can create a variety of modes and then nest them by referring them to each-other conditionally. For instance, I have my geofencing mode pointing to a scheduled mode, which in turn points to multiple static modes.  When at home, I get one set of behaviors at some hours and different behaviors at other hours.  While away, I get yet a different set of behaviors.  I could select any of these static modes as the current "active" mode, or I can chose to refer to them conditionally with other modes as desired.  It's very easy to configure and the specific sub-settings (such as motion sensitivity) are unique to each mode, allowing for a huge degree of variability between modes.  This basically means I can leave my house in a highly-monitored state, but still have my front door watched while I'm home during the day and then switch to more active full-yard monitoring at night when nobody should be in my yard. It is also possible to trigger recording on one camera from an event on another camera, meaning you can record multiple perspectives of an event even if only one camera detects motion or sound. The truly-wireless nature of the cameras means I can mount them in places that might be impractical or less-than-aesthetically-ideal otherwise.  The base station also has quite a decent range.  I have the cameras covering about a third of an acre from the outside in and have not had any connectivity issues, which is extra impressive considering that the cameras link with the base station over the extremely interference-prone 2.4GHz spectrum via WiDi.  There's also very little compression artifacting in the camera feed (only showing up when things get very busy on-camera), though it's worth noting that I have all my cameras set to "highest quality" mode, rather than the balanced mode or battery-focused mode, so that may change with difference modes. The cameras are quite small and the optional weather-hooded sleeves add more color options, meaning they can be quite discrete even when mounted in clear view.  I have yet to have anybody spot the cameras before having them pointed out, and mine are not in well-hidden locations. IR night vision range is quite solid and pretty glare-free.  In fact, while the manual recommends against pointing the cameras in the direction of windows, I experience no glare or washing out despite having all 3 of my cameras aimed at a house with IR-reflective-tinted windows.  A nice bonus is that each camera will activate its own IR lighting, meaning that if two cameras have a view that overlaps, illumination is particularly bright.  And since it's possible to trigger multiple cameras to record from a single event, this actually comes into useful practice quite frequently. The audio recording is a nice touch, but all my cameras experience enough background hiss that it's not really very useful for recording from any kind of distance.  I am experimenting with disabling microphone audio on certain cameras to improve battery life. If Netgear can fix the major functionality glitches, I will LOVE these cameras.  As they stand, I will most likely be requesting a refund.
title: Great concept, but completely broken functionality.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Peterbuilt9
content: First review of system out the box. Setup was a breeze, considering I have an IT systems engineering degree. Setup for me for two cameras is approximately 20 minutes, with an additional 5 minutes for camera and receiver firmware updates. I would expect a novice can complete setup in the same amount of time. One camera experience about 4-5 minutes extra to reboot after firmware upgrade, but reconnected without issue. Running both cameras in doors in open floor plan home with really good connection to receiver. Software is intuitive with just enough options to not create confusion or complicated functionality. Will test for a few more days, and if still satisfied, will add two additional cameras for external coverage. I gave 5 stars because I believe I got exactly what's being advertised. I'm sure a wired system will out perform this one. However, if you need something with DIY minus the cables. I would recommend giving the Arlo a shot. Okay, a few days into my ARLO, and I've added two additional external cameras. I used both hard mount and suction cup mount (on glass window), and both are sturdy enough for the light-weight cameras. Have not experienced issues with camera functionality as detailed in other reviews. The software is great for configuring custom operation of individual cameras. The video quality could be better. However, considering portability of the system (no wires and no DVR), the trade off is tolerable. A little on the pricy side, but you get that when you want the newest technology. Still worth 5 stars now after operating four cameras.
title: Arlo Holds True...so far.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: P0
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. So as any other person, I ran a plethora of reviews and shopped before I decided to go with this. I bought the Arlo Pro 2 pack and got it in 1 day (thank you Amazon!). I live in FL so I have not had the temperature issues that people have discussed but I'd like to share some thoughts that may not be addressed as often from other reviews: 1. Packaging was a bit difficult to be delicate (in case you are worried about returning) however once all the pieces were out, setup was a breeze. Everything was hooked up and synced within 10 minutes. I had a couple firmware updates on the hub and cameras but they updated with no issue. 2. I have not mounted the cameras at all. I plan on placing one outside so I will need to get an extra accessory and the other I plan on using indoors but on the table mount (another accessory). The magnets are strong though. 3. I have been live streaming through PC and iPhone on the hour and batteries are still at 100%! 4. Web app is awesome. Very little lag but it is minimal. If I'm not on wifi (using crappy Tmo 4G), live feed can be impossible. 5. The monitoring options are great. I like how I can tell one camera to start recording if the other camera sees motion /hears noise. This is great if you have dogs! I say this because I am currently using the outside one inside pointing out the window and the motion sensor does not work through a window! But if your dog is barking bc they hear someone outside, your camera pointing outside will record! I posted pic and video for some insight if you are someone who cannot have the camera outside. The only limitation is the outside area must be lit otherwise the LEDs will just white out the screen. I can understand someone complaining that this is a weak line of defense but honestly, if you are truly concerned about being burglarized, you should have a monitoring security system anyways. Paired this with Arlo, you can dispatch police and give adequate details so I feel good about this. I have had a dispatch on a false positive before and they were at my home within 5min so I think if that is good enough for you, then Arlo would be a great 2nd line of defense for you. All other concerns have been addressed plenty of times in other reviews so I will just keep this short. I hope this will help you in deciding if Arlo is right for you or not. I plan on buying Arlo Q in the future and Netgear has announced the Arlo GO if that is something you want to wait on. Overall, I am very satisfied and will update in a few months.
title: Not bad if you are pointing out the window

author: Joe Catanzaro
content: ARLP PRO Review PROS: *Very easy setup. *Very nice and easy to use app. *Cameras are small and sleek. *Skins add a nice touch. *Solar panel = huge plus! Must have! *Parts are accessible and cheap. *Basic 7 day Cloud storage free, nice! *Subscription Cloud prices are priced fairly. CONS: *Resolution is ok, feel it should be better given that most everything in our lives are hi-def.  These cams are at best 720p. *Continuous recording is not an option.  It should be if plugged in. *No prerecord option! This would be extremely helpful for all motion recordings.  Most all other surveillance systems offer this. *No contrast/sharpness option. *Needs better brightness levels.  Its either a tad dark or way too bright. *No available access point equipment specifically designed for these cams to enhance range.  Medium/ large houses need them for these cameras to work properly. SUMMARY: Would highly recommend to home owners looking for a simple way to surveil their property.  With future developments in software, these cameras will be a solid product.
title: *Very easy setup. *Very nice and easy to use app

author: Sisko
content: The Arlo system has terrible lag when the cameras actually connect. The IOS app only allows a few minutes of real time viewing and only after you "activate" a camera by selecting it. Doing this disables its recording function so you'd have to manually start that as well. I am used to Nest, where I can view 4 cameras in real time simultaneously on my phone, without needing to wake any of the cameras or disrupting their recording settings. The Arlo may provide 7 days of cloud for free but it doesn't make up for the horrible app controls or terrible lag. The lag is so bad that I watched myself turn around in front of the camera, after I had stopped it was a full two seconds before the view on the app caught up to real time. Netgear confirmed these cameras have lag and there isn't anything to eliminate it.
title: Camera lag and a poorly conceived app.

content: I purchased this product because it worked with the Samsung hub as well as the Battery capability for the video, I received the product and attempted the install, after doing several things, I resigned myself to call the support at Netgear. I am a software engineer, so I do know a few things about networks and setups. The support had me basically trial and error to get the first one to work , finally gave up and told me to send back for replacement. second one arrived,  Same issues, nothing worked. thru the netgear email support, I disabled firewalls, reset the base station, reset both modem and router, and over 3 days tried everything they had. No go!! Here is my thoughts as a Software developer. there is NO interface that you can get to to determine why or what is the error, routers and other items have a internal Webpage to administrate the device. ANY product that will work with networks as far as I am concerned should have it, I have wasted hours to not get this to work. Netgear with all its capabilities dropped the ball here.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: TnIan
content: Pros: 100% wireless, so you can put them anywhere (within range of the base station indoors or out). The magnet in the back is a bonus for that. Amazingly easy setup (easier than I'd like, actually; I'd prefer a little more manual control). The accompanying mobile app is well done. Image quality is very good relative to other cameras in this category. Cons: Since they're engineered to save battery life, they use a passive infrared receiver to detect motion. That means you can't set up detection zones within the image to minimize false alarms. The threaded camera mount is on the back, not the bottom, so a lot of existing tripods, etc. don't work well. The website requires Flash to play your video clips (seriously, Netgear, if I'd know that beforehand, that might've been a deal-killer). I haven't had them long enough to evaluate battery life, but so far so good.
title: Excellent, with a few caveats

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Teravaxis
content: I spent a lot of time researching security cameras/systems before deciding on the Arlo. The first thing I noticed on receipt was the design of the packaging. A lot of clever design went into just the shipping materials and I felt that if Netgear put as much ingenuity into their product as they did with the packaging, I was probably going to be a satisfied customer. The product itself is elegantly designed and the control functions are both complete and easy to learn. The optics, resolution, night vision, motion sensing and remote notification all perform as advertised. The only problem I had with the setup was getting the base station to see the internet. I have U-verse and had to learn about the arcane art of port forwarding, which basically amounts to editing your firewall settings to let Netgear have access. (Check your "gateway settings" if you do have U-verse and are having problems; it becomes pretty straightforward at that point.) The Arlo system has thus far exceeded my expectations. Netgear has done an excellent job with this product line. I highly recommend it if you are looking for a very high quality home security system.
title: Very impressive by all measures

content: Among few other professional IP cameras, I own both - Arlo and Arlo Pro, and I use them all for security around the house. I have to say, Arlo's are my favorite cameras for a few reasons: for one, they are wireless and can be installed anywhere within the range of the access point. The picture is great day and night. I have motion alert enabled and I get no false alarms. Both camera versions are weather-sealed and I have no problem with the ones that I have outdoors under open sun and rain. I have never tried the feature, but I like to know that if I ever have to use the built-in siren, with its 100+ decibel, it will knock the socks off of intruders. I also like the Arlo app on my phone and the battery - is amazing: I have them protecting my house for about 4 months now, day and night, and still have 45% of battery charge left! I highly recommend the Arlo product! Oh, and if you ever run into a problem, the customer service is superb too!

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Scott Mathison
content: After reading a lot about all of the competition in this space, the Arlo Pro was the winner. I bought the Arlo Pro 4-pack. -100% wireless works well, but don't expect it to record 24/7 recording (it's default settings work well). It uses motion/audio to trigger recording. -Video quality is really good for a surveillance camera (surveillance systems are something I evaluate/price/buy professionally). Night vision is even better than daytime. -The batteries come precharged. Be careful where you point the camera or how sensitive you set its motion activation as it can drain battery ridiculously fast if you point it at a busy road/sidewalk. -Charging was a HUGE unknown plus. After being too overzealous with my recording (I was able to drain one of the cameras' batteries in a day or two) I charged one camera from 5% to full in about an hour! I was expecting at least overnight charging. -IFTTT support! If you are getting into smart home stuff then these cameras can function as de facto motion sensors for lights. After going through quite a few different motion sensing lights for my front door (never could get one that wouldn't trigger on people walking by), I positioned a camera down my stairs and installed a smartswitch for my light and created an IFTTT trigger that would turn on the light when the camera detected motion. Works WAY better than any of the dozens of motion sensing lights that are supposed to be built for the purpose. The only catch is it doesn't care if it is night or day, but in my case it still turns the light on far less often and should save me some bulbs in the long run. IFTTT has been so powerful in replacing light timers in my house that this section could go on forever. Needless to say, if you have any intention of going smart home, this is the only good choice in town -These things are very compact; less than the size of an average fist -Weatherproof. The fact they are able to get such a high-quality camera in a weatherproof case for this cost is going to change how I negotiate the next time I have to buy cameras for work. -Smartthings integration. Integration is not working properly. I was able to add the cameras in the beginning, but now they can't be removed/changed/updated in the Smartthings app. I am not willing to reset the app to fix it, so it'll just have to stay broken until an update fixes it. -Wifi range. I don't particularly like having another hub, but it is a necessary evil and the connection between the cameras reaches places my normal WiFi couldn't come close to (until I bought a Google OnHub). -Android app. I have heard the iPhone app is more reliable, but the Android app is still pretty good. Functionally it is well done, I just notice that it has glitches while using it. -Website. LIVE VIEW STILL USES FLASH! This should be #1,2, and 3. No one should be using Flash for anything, especially not for a live camera into what could be private areas of your home. To clarify, if you want to view recorded video, you don't need flash, but if you want to view live view of your camera you HAVE to use Flash. And if you didn't know; Flash is terrible, insecure, and so bad the company who made it recommends not using it anymore...It is a big enough problem that I would suggest not buying this product at all if you need to use the website to view live video. -Dynamic range. This is basically the cameras' ability to handle varying light conditions, like what happens when the sun shines right into the lens and the camera has to adjust so that it doesn't go blind. This camera handles it very well, but don't expect anything on the level of the Pixel phone. Some spots will be blown out, but the video is still useful. -Cloud storage. 7-days free cloud storage AND unlimited local storage is so awesome it easily trumps all other competitors by itself. In fact, due to this there really isn't a good second choice. This is definitely #1 and everything else is a very distant second, including the non-pro version of the Arlo base station. Continuous monitoring would be better but it's not how this model was designed to work.  Maybe in a future update?  I haven't had it long enough to experience the "end of recorded clip" issue but I do hope they have a fix for it.  It would be a shame to miss recording part of an important event.  I plan on adding more cameras now that the first one has been successful.

content: It's not the cheapest camera system out there, but I'm really glad I spent the extra bucks for the ease of use and features. The system was dead simple to set up (I appreciate the camera batteries all coming fully charged), and the flexibility lives up to the marketing materials. - Well designed app - Geofencing works (Some people have mentioned issues with it, and while it did take a bit of tweaking to ensure the system was properly  registering BOTH my wife and my phone, now it works perfectly - Good video and audio quality. The two way talk works great. - Motion alerts kick in accurately and fast. My cameras are indoors, but haven't had a false positive yet (moving shadows, etc). - Didn't even realize when purchasing that there is an Apple TV app, but it also works pretty well if you want to do some simple checking of your camera feeds. All in all, really satisfied.

author: BethS
content: Arlo pro is a great system. It’s hard to believe they can cram so much tech into such small, weather-proof devices. The video and audio playback is amazing. I can’t believe the sound these things pick up. You can totally customize your system for the different times of day or different circumstances. I’ve had this system about a year and have just recently charged the cameras for the second time so the battery life is amazing. We use this system several times a day so it is not the type of thing you get bored with and stop using after a while. In fact, we just now after a year added an additional camera. The setup is quick and easy. I can find out whether packages were delivered to the front porch, or see if I left the garage door open. Best of all, I now know whether the mother in law is visiting by looking at the driveway cam and can quick text my wife,  “I’m going to be home Home late tonight Hun!” Disaster averted. The interface is great, and can easily be used by the kids. It's really great to be able to control the whole system from your cell at anytime.I also love how you don’t need to pay a monthly fee for security and they provide cloud storage free of charge. I don’t say this much about new products but I simply couldn’t be happier! Thanks Netgear, a company that finally gets it!

author: Forsyth Fan
content: I have a system running two original Arlo cams and now have added two Arlo Pros to the mix. (Note: All run well off of the original base station.) I love this system because it just works. No sunscription needed, easy to pair and set up and the image quality and alerts are good quality and reliable. Battery life for me has been strong, running several months for the original cams and looks like the Pros are on the same path. I view live video a few times a day and generally have a handful of motion alerts, so I would consider this average use. Mine have held up well in rain and snow, hot and very cold temps without issue. Only gripes: Takes 10-15 seconds before live video appears from when you open the appp; there is a lag between when motion is detected and video is recorded, so you miss a wider shot sometimes of what triggered the alert (you can turn up motion sensitivity but then get a lot of false alerts); and the range of the base station could be a bit better. Bravo Netfear for producing a system that just works.
title: Best balance of features and ease of use

author: Steven Balcerzak
content: The Camera works very well, but I had trouble updating and syncing the camera to the base because the base software updated automatically, but the camera software didn't update at the same time because the camera wouldn't stay connected to the base. After talking with customer service and trying a few things, we finally got the camera to update, but only after several tries and logging in and out of the phone app. After that, the camera is worked very well, but the battery life was much shorter than I anticipated. I'm guessing that the 6 months advertised battery life is only if the camera is activated occasionally, not always on. Although I was a little frustrated with the updating problem that I had (I was really excited to get it working right away), once that was fixed I felt that the camera worked very well, and minus the updating problem, was exactly what was advertised. It was very easy to set up, mount, look at videos, very versatile and had free cloud storage (for up to 5 cameras for 7 days).
title: Great Camera, had update problems

content: The camera system is great! The batteries last a long time, the motion sensing is spot on, the push/email notifications are great. The only real downside to this system is the Android app (I don't have an IOS device so I can't review based on that - sorry) Sometimes it's a bit buggy. Sometimes it takes a long time to get the status of your devices (even when you have a good internet connection), sometimes (rarely) it asks you to scan your fingerprint more than once and then bugs out (though, I absolutely love the fact that it has fingerprint support - I think any developer who implements this is awesome), and (always) talking through the Android app out the camera speaker is so soft I didn't even think it worked at first (but I didn't buy it for this, it would just be cooler if it worked). Overall, I think the system is great. The bad points seem numerous because I didn't really go into the good points, but there's definitely more pros than cons.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: A. Jozefowicz
content: Great product! A tech product that enables the user with few complications. Crazy simple to setup. Criticisms: Would like a fresh snapshot from each cam when initially opening app. Would like the text alert to contain a snapshot of movement just to see if i need to start fiddling with my phone. Would like to be able to toggle text/email notifications when movement/sound is detected. I.e., if expecting amazon delivery, need an alert sent for the front door occasionally but would always like to have a backlog of recordings. Modifying some settings can be a little wonky at times. Would like to be able to create deadzones in the camera to completely disregard any movement. A camera 6 feet from a walking cat will always send an alert no matter the sensitivity.  I had to get creative with cam positioning. Grant access function is great but if you give it to your housekeeper, she can use the app to look inside your home at any time. This is a problem. Until it is fixed, simply have a visitor call you to disarm home. Overall a great product and i would suggest to most people that would like a home security solution. Gives me total peace of mind when i am away and despite some issues that you can correct for it is in my opinion the best single solution to home security. This product also works great with some battery powered water leak detection devices that have an audible alarm. The cameras will pick up the sounds and i get an alert on my phone immediately! Would like in future versions the ability of the device to alert the user if the garage door is open (for example). Possibly without even a sensor, just alert user if the user leaves the geofencing area without a particular zone looking a certain way.
title: Awesome product! Covers all bases.

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: hurrah
content: Overall great camera. My main concerns were mounting and remote live viewing. Mounting was generally pretty painless, but the mount simply hangs on a single nail. If the camera is placed perpendicular to the wall, it works fine. But I needed to mount it in a corner so it would need to be about 45 degrees from the wall and pointing downwards. If the mount is not perfectly in the corner with the mount right up next to the other wall, the entire mount will swing and you probably won't get the right angle. I had to remount it to get this right. Remote live viewing works very well, even in the dark. Starting the app and going into live view takes quite a while though - maybe around 15-20 seconds. In an unexpected situation, it might seem quite long if you want to immediately know what's going on.
title: Great camera

content: Very good product for a single house.  we tried this for the last year and were happy with most of the features.  its a bit slow on starting the video.  If someone walks by the camera in less than 2 seconds you miss them completely.  My main reason for the low score was i bought another unit for our vacation home in the mountains  (yes another $450 )  Even if you buy another base station and separate system they want you to upgrade for an additional $100 per year to see the other house!  this is crazy.  If my wife (or anyone else) signed up for another account it would be free.  Why would you penalize anyone for buying more of your product?  I could see it if i was buying more cameras for the same house/base station.  so if you never want to add another system to another location then i would buy it.  if you more than one  I would find another provider..

author: Robert Boswell
content: I purchased this camera because I needed a wireless 1080p camera that I could communicate through.  I read all the reviews and decided on this one. My first camera was easy to set up, however the "push to talk" did not work. I tried everything...nothing.  I finally broke down and called tech support.  What a waste of my time.  They could not fix the problem. I ended up returning and exchanging thinking I got a defective camera.  The 2nd camera had the exact same problem. Once again after trouble shooting and calling tech support, they finally informed me that the IOS11.3 does not work with their camera and that their engineers were working on it.  They informed me that they would contact me with a solution.  The next email I received from them was that they were closing my case...WHAT? That made no sense to me.  I informed them that their product advertises push to talk but they do not have a solution to this feature which is not working.  This is false advertising.  I will be returning this product.  This is my first review of a product. So disappointed.
title: IOS users Stay Away From This Product

product: Arlo Pro - Wireless Home Security Camera System with Siren | Rechargeable, Night vision, Indoor/Outdoor, HD Video, 2-Way Audio, Wall Mount | Cloud Storage Included | 5 camera kit (VMS4530)
author: Brandon Jones
content: This has been an amazing product. Without home security we felt like we were flying in the dark with blinders on. The Arlo by netgear works seemlessly with our netgear router and has really great range. It still picks up a signal all the way across a two story home to outside front door. I passed on using the magnet mount and instead went with the other screw in mount that can be mounted above front door. I used ladder and mounted it high enough that would be bad guys couldn't remove it. The picture quality isn't grainy and looks crystal clear. Even at night works well. It does pick up all movement in front of camera field of sight so be prepared for lots of 10 sec recordings. I did change settings to 15 sec because I wanted a bit longer record time. I also went with the pro account for $10 a month because it offered more. I'm already planning on getting 1-2 more cameras around home. Thank you Netgear for making a quality product that everyone can operate and control. The only downside (which isn't that big a deal) is that I have to take ladder outside and remove camera from mount when I need to charge it monthly. I'm thinking I might plug in charge cable and use extension cord to charge without removing from mount. Not sure if that is recommended though. Anyway, I just love this product
title: Quality product from Netgear and worth the money

author: Irish I Was Tan
content: I love being able to keep an eye on my house when I'm gone, or take a look outside when I've heard a suspicious noise from the comfort of my bed. The minor complaint: I'm not crazy about the limited options for mounts or at least that the after-market mounts all have bad reviews. The major complaints: A) The volume of the audio-out is minuscule. Hardly more than a whisper most of the time. We have decent connectivity. The audio-in is fantastic. The picture is pretty darn good even on the mid-range setting. But that audio-out is hardly the frightening voice of God I'd hoped for if I need to deter a prowler. B) I contacted the company after realizing there was a dead pixel on one of the cameras. They gave me so much grief, making excuse after excuse. I get they have to triage issues before they just up and replace a camera, but when increasing the camera's resolution (their recommendation to get rid of it) makes the pixel more pronounced, and bringing the camera closer to the base station doesn't improve it. It was one thing after the next... do this, do that. It wasn't enough that I had demonstrated over and over and over again that the pixel was steadily dead no matter the relationship it had to the base station and the internet speed they even wanted a comparison of the two cameras side by side near the base station. They finally sent an RMA for return after weeks of multiple emails and online chats with tech support.
title: Not bad.
